{{unreferenced|date=May 2012}} {{Motorsport season |series = Norwegian Touring Car Championship |year = 2003 |previous = 2002 }} The '''2003 Norwegian Touring Car Championship season''' was the 2nd of 3 seasons of the championship. It was decided over six race weekends (comprising twelve races) at three different circuits. {{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2011 Djiboutian protests | partof = the [[Arab Spring]] | image = Location Djibouti AW.png | caption = | date = {{start date|2011|01|28}} – {{end date|2011|03|11}}
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=01|day1=28|year1=2011|month2=03|day2=11|year2=2011}}) | place = [[Djibouti]] | coordinates = | causes = | goals = Remove president [[Ismail Omar Guelleh]] from power | methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]], [[riot]]s. | status = | result = Mass arrests of protesters and opposition leaders,
deprivation of international observers | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = At least 2 fatalities | leadfigures2 = 10 injuries | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | casualties_label = | notes = }} The '''2011 Djiboutian protests''' were widespread demonstrations and riots that took place between January and March 2011 in [[Djibouti]], situated in the [[Horn of Africa]]. A member of the [[Arab League]], the protests in Djibouti showed a clear [[Impact of the Arab Spring|influence]] from the concurrent [[Arab Spring]] protests in [[North Africa]] and the [[Arabian peninsula]]. The demonstrations ended after mass arrests and the barring of international observers. ==Background== President of Djibouti [[Ismail Omar Guelleh]] has been in office since 1999, but his government has been in power for 34 years. Recently, Guelleh changed the constitution so that he could have a third term in office. This proved unpopular with the Djiboutian population.[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/mar/06/af-djibouti-protests/ Police, army forces in Djibouti prevent protest - Sunday, March 6, 2011 | 3:02 a.m. - Las Vegas Sun]{{dead link|date=July 2015}} These protests occurred in the months leading up to the [[Djiboutian presidential election, 2011]]. ==Protests== ===Before February 19=== On January 25, thousands of people turned out to protest in Djibouti City. Similar to the events on January 28, only smaller. 300 people gathered in a square in the capital, [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]]. On February 18, thousands rallied against the president, gathering at a stadium with the intention of staying there until their demands were met. However, the demonstration escalated into clashes after dusk, as police used batons and tear gas against stone-throwing protesters. Officials from the Union for Democratic Change, an umbrella group of three opposition parties, gave speeches at the demonstration calling for Guelleh to step down.{{cite news|title=Djiboutians rally to oust president|author =|publisher=[[Aljazeera English]]|date=18 February 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121816513686216.html}} ===February 19–25=== On February 19, clashes were reported to be intensifying.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20110219-321179/Djibouti-police-protestors-face-off-for-second-day |title=Djibouti police, protestors face off for second day |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} Anti-government protestors clashed with security forces 24 hours after hundreds of demonstrators demanding the president step down hurled stones at riot police who fired back with tear gas. At least one policeman was killed, and sources said one protester had also been killed.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Middle-East-Unrest-Bloody-Clashes-Between-Protesters-And-Police-Claim-Dozens-Of-Lives/Article/201102315936935?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15936935_Middle_East_Unrest:_Bloody_Clashes_Between_Protesters_And_Police_Claim_Dozens_Of_Lives |title=Middle East Unrest: Bloody Clashes Between Protesters And Police Claim Dozens Of Lives |publisher=Sky News |date=|accessdate=19 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2015}} The protest leaders were arrested{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-djibouti-protests-idUSTRE71I1BQ20110219 | work=Reuters | title=Protests hit Djibouti as opposition leaders held | date=19 February 2011}} The next day, Djiboutian authorities released three opposition leaders as opponents of President Ismail Guelleh clashed with police.[http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-19/djibouti-opposition-leaders-free-after-anti-government-protests.html Djibouti Opposition Leaders Free After Anti-Government Protests - Businessweek] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222115430/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-19/djibouti-opposition-leaders-free-after-anti-government-protests.html |date=February 22, 2011 }} Leaders of the United Sun Nations, opposition parties and protest organisers were set to meet on February 24 to plan mass protests for the following day. Police acting on behalf of Gulleh arrested 300 organisers during and after the mass protests on February 18, with reports of torture being used to sedate the activists. After the failure of the leaders to turn up on February 24, opposition leader [[Bourhan Mohammed Ali]] stated he feared the protests had lost momentum.[http://www.afrol.com/articles/37449 afrol News - Mass arrests stopped further Djibouti protests] Protests had been planned for March 4, but it remained to be seen if the Djiboutians would be able to coordinate themselves without the 300 arrested leaders. ===February 26 – March 11=== On March 3, [[Djibouti]] ordered its opposition party to cancel its anti-government protests which were to be held on March 4, 2011 due to a previous rally a month earlier turning violent. [[Mohammed Daoud]], head of the opposition [[Djibouti Party for Development]], said that protests will occur as scheduled.{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/djiboutiNews/idAFLDE7220AJ20110303 | title=Djibouti orders opposition to postpone protest | accessdate=4 March 2011 | others=Reporting by Abdourahem Arteh in Djibouti and Richard Lough in Nairobi | author=Richard Lough|editor=David Clarke | publisher=Reuters | date=3 March 2011}} On the 4th soldiers and police filled the streets to prevent the planned demonstration blocking the route to the city's main stadium where they were to have taken place and preventing the protest. A protest was planned for March 11, but security forces scuppered the protest and detained 4 opposition leaders.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/djibouti-forces-arrest-opposition-leaders-scuppering-protests.html |title=Djibouti Forces Arrest Opposition Leaders, Scuppering Protests |publisher=[[Bloomberg Television|Bloomberg.com]] |accessdate=3 November 2011 |date=11 March 2011}} ==Censorship== On February 9, the President of the Djibouti League of Human Rights was arrested.{{cite news|title=Djibouti: Human rights activist arrested in Djibouti: Jean-Paul Noёl Abdi|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/AFR23/001/2011/en|accessdate=24 March 2011|date=11 February 2011|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110313150842/http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/AFR23/001/2011/en| archivedate= 13 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} On March 21, [[US]] election monitors were expelled from the country, whose task would have been to observe the [[Djiboutian presidential election, 2011|April 2011 presidential election]].{{cite news|last=Straziuso|first=Jason|title=Djibouti evicts US vote group ahead of election|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42141308|accessdate=24 March 2011|newspaper=[[Associated Press]]|date=18 March 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2015}} ==Response== The [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] warned against travel to [[Djibouti]].{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Simon|title=FCO travel advice mapped: the world according to Britain's diplomats|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2011/mar/23/fco-travel-advice-map|accessdate=24 March 2011|newspaper=[[guardian.co.uk]] Datablog|date=23 March 2011|location=London}} ==See also== * [[Djiboutian presidential election, 2011]] * [[Arab Spring]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Arab Spring}} {{Anti-government protests in the 21st century}} [[Category:Politics of Djibouti]] {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = 60th anniversary of the People's Republic of China |Image_Name = China-60.svg |Imagesize = 250 |Image_Alt = red logo in the shape of the number '60' |Image_Caption = Logo for the 60th anniversary of the PRC |AKA = 中华人民共和国成立六十周年庆典 |Date = {{Start date|2009|10|01|df=y}} |URL = [http://www.chinaview.cn/60thprc/ Xinhua]
[http://english.people.com.cn/90002/97623/index.html People's Daily]
[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/60th/index.html China Daily]
[http://www.globaltimes.cn/www/english/feature-template/2009-09/472836.html Global Times]{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} }} {{Chinese|title name=60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China|s=中华人民共和国成立六十周年庆典|t=中華人民共和國成立六十周年慶典|p=Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó Chénglì Liùshí Zhōunián Qìngdiǎn|order=st}} The '''60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of [[China]]''' took place on 1 October 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/60th/index.html |title=60th Anniversary of the People's Republic of China |work=China Daily }} A [[military parade]] involving 10,000 troops and the display of many high-tech weapons was held in [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]] and various celebrations were conducted all over the country. [[Hu Jintao]] inspected the troops along [[Chang'an Avenue]] in Beijing. This parade was immediately followed by a civilian parade involving 100,000 participants. ==Background== [[Image:Tiananmengatepic1.jpg|thumb|250px|The 60th Anniversary Military Parade took place on [[Chang'an Avenue]], beneath [[Tiananmen]].]] The People's Republic of China was founded on 1 October 1949. Since then, celebrations of varying scales occur on [[National Day of the People's Republic of China|National Day]] each year. [[Military parade]]s, presided over by Chairman [[Mao Zedong]], were held every year between 1949 and 1959. In September 1960, the Chinese leadership decided that in order to save funds and "be frugal", large-scale ceremonies for National Day would only be held every ten years, with a smaller-scale ceremony every five years.{{cite web |url=http://mil.eastday.com/eastday/mil/node3043/node33436/userobject1ai542876.html |title=Wei Jianfeng: Looking back at 13 military parades since the founding of the PRC |language=Chinese |work=東方軍事 (Eastday) |access-date=16 September 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926125224/http://mil.eastday.com/eastday/mil/node3043/node33436/userobject1ai542876.html |archive-date=26 September 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The last large-scale celebration during the Mao era was in 1969. Large-scale celebrations did not take place for 14 years amidst the climax of the [[Cultural Revolution]]. Since then, the most prominent National Day celebrations have taken place in 1984 and 1999, at the 35th and 50th anniversaries respectively. During these celebrations, then-[[paramount leader]] [[Deng Xiaoping]] and [[Jiang Zemin]] reviewed military parades of the [[People's Liberation Army]]. The 2009 parade was the first and last time [[Hu Jintao]] oversaw this task, as he left office in 2012 due to term limits.{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26150813-25837,00.html | work=The Australian | first=Michael | last=Sainsbury | title=China marks 60th anniversary of communist rule | date=1 October 2009}} ==Preparations== [[File:Prominent banner for the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China in Shenzhen 20090829.jpg|thumb|250px |Banner in [[Shenzhen]] in late August]] 40 million potted flowers, supplied by the state-owned Beijing Flowers & Trees Corp., were put in place in Beijing streets, approximately 5 million of which have been planted along the east-west axis of [[Chang'an Avenue]], also known as 'Avenue of Eternal Peace'. Flowers in Tiananmen Square were under 24-hour surveillance; Beijing Jinggong Red Flag factory is producing 2 million national flags for the celebrations.{{cite news |url=http://english.sina.com/china/p/2009/0914/270586.html |title=Flowers decorate streets of Beijing |date=15 September 2009 |author=China Daily |work=[[Sina.com]]}} In Tiananmen Square itself, 56 "pillars of national unity" – each one symbolizing the [[List of ethnic groups in China|56 ethnic groups in China]] – were erected, with each containing fireworks for the night event on 1 October.{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2009-09/15/content_8693109.htm | title='Pillars of National Unity' set up in Tian'anmen Square |work=China Daily | date=15 September 2009 }} 800,000 volunteers controlled crowds and maintained order while a further 30,000 provided translation services at subway and bus stations.{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_434642.html |title=Excitement over China's N-Day |date=26 September 2009 |author=Ng, Grace |work=[[The Straits Times]]}} Mosquitoes, rats, flies, and cockroaches were the targets of professional exterminators – four unannounced night-time sweeps were carried out around [[Tiananmen Square]] in Beijing, including in the [[Forbidden City]] complex. The public was encouraged to support the eradication through red slogan banners along Beijing streets and alleys, in what ''The Times'' said was reminiscent of the [[Great sparrow campaign|Four Pests campaign]]. One of these slogans read: “Eradicate the four pests, stress hygiene. Cleanly, cleanly welcome National Day!”{{cite news |date=3 September 2009 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6819291.ece |title=China wages war on pests before 60th anniversary of Communist rule |first=Jane |last=Macartney |work=The Times | location=London}} Tiananmen Square was sealed off for the day on 29 August for the first rehearsals. Tens of thousands of fully costumed performers rehearsed on 16 September.{{cite news |url=http://english.sina.com/china/p/2009/0916/271083.html |title=Rehearsal for National Day celebration held in Beijing |date=17 September 2009 |author=Xinhua |work=Sina.com}} The military also prepared, with several hundred vehicles rolling down Chang'an Avenue on 6 September.{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_426284.html |title=60th anniversary rehearsal |date=6 September 2009 |author=AP |work=[[The Straits Times]]}} parts of Beijing were closed down on 18 September for the final rehearsals of the anniversary parade. Police cleared streets and office buildings on the main roadways near Tiananmen Square from noon onwards for rehearsals that evening. State media went into overdrive, for example, highlighting how thousands of troops spent four months drilling to march in step on a mock practice ground with scale model of Chang'an Avenue - complete with the leadership reviewing stand.{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gvlZSXX-y0QT5V6gSSabSp9SiYpwD9APQCJO2 |title=Dry run: Beijing shuts early for parade practice |first=Charles |last=Hutzler |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=19 September 2009 }} Following disruptions caused by the drills, which shut down roads and large parts of the [[Beijing Subway]], ''[[Xinhua News Agency]]'' announced that the final rehearsal parade, scheduled for 26 September, was called off.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE58I07U20090919 |work=Reuters |title=Beijing cancels National Day rehearsal after disruptions |date=18 September 2009 | first=Ben | last=Blanchard}} ===Security=== ''The Sunday Times'' reported that "thousands of agents will stage a security clampdown exceeding anything seen for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Olympic Games]]".{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6850841.ece |work=The Sunday Times |date=27 September 2009 |title=China reaches out on 60th anniversary |first=Michael |last=Sheridan | location=London}} Police in Beijing and neighbouring provinces were in a heightened state of readiness, with night patrols by armed police lasting from 15 September until the end of the festivities. All basements in the city were subject to inspection by police, while some restaurants with roof terraces were not permitted to seat patrons on sides overlooking the street for the duration. However, despite the supposed high alert around Beijing, a man armed with a knife killed two people and injured 12 in the heart of Beijing on 17 September.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/17/beijing-stabbings-national-day-tiananmen |title=Stabbings in Beijing ahead of National Day |first=Tania |last=Branigan |work=The Guardian |date=17 September 2009 | location=London}} Peter Ford of the ''[[The Christian Science Monitor|Christian Science Monitor]]'' said that the stabbing incident had been played down locally.{{cite web |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/09/18/china-covers-up-tiananmen-knifing-amid-60th-anniversary-security-boost/ |title=China covers up Tiananmen knifing amid 60th anniversary security boost |first=Peter |last=Ford |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=17 September 2009}} Following the attacks, however, the knives were removed from sale at some stores such as [[Wal-Mart]] and [[Carrefour]].{{cite news |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=10&art_id=88186&sid=25441005&con_type=1&d_str=20090922&sear_year=2009 |title=Security overdrive as Beijing readies for show of a lifetime |work=The Standard |author=Associated Press |date=22 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004223402/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=10&art_id=88186&sid=25441005&con_type=1&d_str=20090922&sear_year=2009 |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=101998&z=5 Trung Hoa “làm sạch” trung tâm thủ đô chuẩn bị lễ Quốc Khánh] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091201013456/http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=101998&z=5 |date=1 December 2009 }} {{vi}} Thousands of paramilitary officers were deployed at bridges, road tunnels and other strategic points in the city.{{cite news |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/eastasia/view/1005844/1/.html |title=China tightens security ahead of anniversary celebrations |work=[[Channel NewsAsia]] |last= Wong |first=Yee Fong |date= 19 September 2009}} Residents were warned that if they stepped out onto balconies along the route, they might be shot. 30,000 people with tickets have been invited to watch the event, but others were encouraged to watch it on television to "avoid complications."{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8284087.stm | title=China set for mass celebrations |publisher=BBC News | date=30 September 2009 }} ''The Times'' says the authorities engaged counter-terrorist units and informers in districts where Xinjiang Muslims live, placed Tibetan Buddhists under surveillance, and arrested dissidents. Peasants coming to the capital to present their grievances as petitions were blocked. while the government ordered the search of all cars entering Beijing. The security drives organised by the Ministry of Public Security in Beijing, as well as neighbouring [[Hebei]], [[Liaoning]], [[Shandong]] and [[Shanxi province]]s, the [[Inner Mongolian Autonomous Region]] and the [[Tianjin Municipality]] was dubbed a "Security Moat" by a senior official. The official said the "safety of China's National Day celebrations and stability in Beijing was of overriding importance."{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/23/content_12100811.htm |title=Senior leader calls for all-inclusive Beijing security checks | work=Chinaviwew |author=Xinhua |date=23 September 2009 }} ''The Times'' reported Internet users saying [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|censorship]] has been tightened: many sites have been blocked, among them Facebook and Twitter; one media analyst said that the authorities upgraded their technology to block free [[proxy server|proxy services]] and were trying to block any free proxy services and [[virtual private network|VPNs]] during the week prior to the anniversary.{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/internet-dissidents-under-watch-for-chinas-national-day-20091001-gcwy.html |title=Internet, dissidents under watch for China's National Day |first=Marianne |last=Barriaux |agency=AFP |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=1 October 2009 }} Other security arrangements in place included relocation of mailboxes and newspaper stands along [[Chang'an Avenue]] and the closure or restricted opening of some of the hotels along the route (ex. the [[Beijing Hotel]], the [[Beijing News Plaza Hotel]], and the [[Beijing International Hotel]]). Other hotels on Chang'an Avenue closed guest rooms facing the main road during the celebrations. ==Media== The government established a media centre from 22 September until 2 October at the [[Media Center Hotel]] catering for journalists covering celebrations. The centre's deputy, Zhu Shouchen, said they received applications from more than 4,500 journalists around the world, including some 1,300 journalists from 346 media organisations in 108 countries. Almost 400 of them were said to be from Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/22/content_12096071.htm |title=China opens media center for coverage of 60th National Day celebrations | work=Chinaviwew |author=Xinhua |date=22 September 2009 }} A film entitled ''[[The Founding of a Republic]]'', commissioned by China's film regulator and made by the [[China Film Group]] (CFG) to mark the anniversary, was released nationwide on 17 September. The film retells the tale of the Communist ascendancy and triumph, with a star-studded cast including [[Zhang Ziyi]], [[Jackie Chan]], [[Jet Li]], and directors [[Jiang Wen]], [[Chen Kaige]] and [[John Woo]] in mostly cameos appearances; the leading roles – such as [[Mao Zedong]] – were played by lesser known actors. CFG chairman [[Han Sanping]] co-directed the film with [[Huang Jianxin]]. A CFG spokesman said many stars answered Han's call to appear in the film and waived their fee, helping it keep its modest budget of 60–70 million yuan (US$8.8–$10 million). According to the executive at one of China's top multiplex chains, the film unusually married "the core of an 'ethically inspiring' film" – code for propaganda films, according to the Associated Press – "with commercial packaging."{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jC9FHUhmam1K9PqXuyaKZDnjzH3AD9AFNKOO0 |title=China injects star power into anniversary film |first=Min |last=Lee |agency=AP |date=3 September 2009}} ==Parades== [[File:Self-propelled howitzer in front of Gucci.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A [[PLZ-89]] [[self-propelled howitzer]] passes the Shin Kong Place Luxury shopping centre during a training exercise, Beijing.]] ===Leaders=== [[Liu Qi (politician)|Liu Qi]], as the Beijing municipal Communist Party [[CPC party chief|Secretary]], was the [[master of ceremonies]] for the event. [[Hu Jintao]], in his position as the General Secretary of the Communist Party, President of the People's Republic, and Chairman of the Central Military Commission, presided over the military parade. In addition, all members of the [[Politburo Standing Committee]] at the time, along with the former General Secretary, President [[Jiang Zemin]], stood atop [[Tiananmen]] in [[Political position ranking of the People's Republic of China|protocol order]] for the entire duration of the parade. Other prominent retired leaders, including former Premiers [[Li Peng]] and [[Zhu Rongji]], and former Vice-President [[Zeng Qinghong]] were also in attendance. ===Military parade=== The military parade took place on [[Chang'an Avenue]], with the country's leaders watching the parade from [[Tiananmen]], above Mao's portrait. Hu Jintao inspected the troops standing onto a [[FAW Hongqi|Hongqi]] [[Hongqi HQE|HQE]] limousine designed for the event, with a special license plate ('''[[Vehicle registration plates of China#Beijing|京V]] 02009'''). For the anniversary, the Chinese government budgeted roughly $44 million for the military parade, with some budget cuts due to the recent global financial crisis.{{cite news |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20090130/119888198.html |title=China to hold frugal 60th anniversary parade |date=30 January 2009 |work=[[RIA Novosti]]}} The parade displayed 52 new types of military hardware, including [[Type 99 tank|ZTZ99]] main battle tanks, [[Chengdu J-10|J-10]] fighter aircraft, [[Shaanxi Y-8|KJ-200]] and [[KJ-2000]] [[Airborne early warning and control|early-warning aircraft]], [[Harbin Z-9|Z-9W]] [[attack helicopter]]s, and new models of the [[QBZ-95|Type 95]] and [[QBZ-03|Type 03]] [[assault rifle]]s.{{cite web | url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/6765794.html | title=Six Most Anticipated 'New Weapons' in the National Day Parade|work=People's Daily | date=23 September 2009}} The five new types of missiles were paraded by the [[Second Artillery Corps (China)|Second Artillery Corps]]. The Second Artillery's display included a total of 108 missiles and was intended to showcase China's strategic deterrence capabilities.''Zhongguo Xinwen She'', "Second Artillery To Debut 5 New [[CCTV-9]] (English) rebroadcast the celebrations at 16:00, 24:00, and 7:00 (2 October). [[China National Radio]] provided live audio coverage throughout [[mainland China]] on CNR channels 1, 2, 3, 4, and 9; the Hong Kong and [[Macau]] region on CNR channel 7; and [[Taiwan]] on CNR channel 5. ==National Day Evening Gala== On the evening of 1 October, from 20:00 to 22:00, a music concert of 28 patriotic Chinese songs was performed with hundreds of dancers in [[Tiananmen Square]], with a series of massive fireworks displays overhead. Early media reports earlier predicted that the fireworks presentation would be "double the firepower of the [[2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|2008 Olympics opening ceremony]]"{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}. A total of 60,700 gold coins with [[face value]]s of [[Chinese yuan|¥]]10,000, 2,000 yuan, and 100 yuan were issued, while a total of 106,000 silver coins with the face values of 300 and 10 yuan issued. All the coins, produced by [[Shenzhen Guobao Mint]] and [[Shenyang Mint]], and distributed by the China Gold Coin Incorporation, are legal tender.{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90778/90857/90859/6746691.html |title=Central Bank to issue coins commemorating 60th anniversary of founding of New China | work=People's Daily |author=Xinhua |date=2 September 2009 }} The obverse of the coins features China's national emblem, set in a frieze of peonies. The reverse includes various designs including a rocket, a satellite, a high-speed train, and the Beijing Olympic Stadium. Other forms will show designs of an open gate, a bridge, or urban construction. They bear Chinese characters saying: "In commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, 1949–2009." On 20 October 2009, the [[China National Philatelic Corporation]] issued three collections in commemoration of the 60th Anniversary. There are two stamp albums priced at ¥380 and ¥680 and a stamp scroll priced at ¥1,280.{{cite web |url=http://www.cpi.com.cn/cpi-eng/product/2009-1020.asp |title=Celebration of The 60th Anniversary of the Founding of the People's Republic of China |publisher=China National Philatelic Corporation |accessdate=30 September 2009}} [[File:HK 60 anniv stamps.png|thumb|right|150px|HK fan-shaped stamps, in souvenir sheet (below)]] [[Hongkong Post]] issues a set of six [[commemorative stamp]]s and a stamp sheetlet on 1 October.{{cite news |url=http://www.hongkongpoststamps.com/eng/newsletter/2009/09/20090917a.htm |title=Special Stamp Issue – '60th Anniversary of the Founding of the People's Republic of China' |work=Hongkong Post Newsletter |date=September 2009 |access-date=27 September 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005073730/http://www.hongkongpoststamps.com/eng/newsletter/2009/09/20090917a.htm |archive-date=5 October 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Unlike most stamps, the set of stamps are fan-shaped and form a circle when placed together (as seen in the souvenir sheet configuration). Their pictorial design is based on the winning entries of a competition: [[Victoria Harbour]] and Tiananmen Square are depicted on two interlocking cogwheels on the $1.40 stamp; the five-star national flag flying by the side of the "Forever Blooming Bauhinia" ($1.80). The [[Beijing National Stadium|Bird's Nest stadium]] is on the $2.40, while China's manned spacecraft [[Shenzhou 7]] is depicted on the $2.50. The [[Temple of Heaven]] features on the $3 value and a golden dragon soaring above the [[Great Wall of China|Great Wall]] adorns the $5 stamp. A souvenir sheet features all six stamps, which form a perfect ring with the accompanying number "6", together forming the number "60". Hong Kong's stamp sheetlet has two $5 stamps in Chinese red, one featuring Beijing and one [[Victoria, Hong Kong|Victoria]]. The National Emblem and [[Tiananmen]] appear on the left and the Regional Emblem above a night view of Hong Kong. ==Outside China== [[File:Empire State Building 1 Oct 2009.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Empire State Building]] lights up in red and yellow on the eve of 1 October.]] The [[Empire State Building]] in New York City lit up in red and yellow lights on 1 October in commemoration of the founding of the People's Republic of China.No author, 28 September 2009, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hUZamhqvPGVrYZpGq_clUpC7dAUg Empire State Building turns red-yellow for China's 60th], AFPAbrams, Joseph, 1 October 2009, [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,557823,00.html Empire State Building Goes Red for Communist China, Sparking Protest], Fox News The display was criticised by some commentators within the United States, with some branding it as an improper gesture towards China.Heye, Doug, 30 September 2009, [https://www.usnews.com/blogs/doug-heye/2009/09/30/the-empire-state-buildings-disgusting-kowtow-to-china.html The Empire State Building's Disgusting Kowtow to China], U.S. News & World Report{{Verify credibility|date=November 2009}}Pan, Kai, 30 September 2009, [http://cnreviews.com/life/news-issues/empire-state-building-60th-anniversary-outrage_20090930.html Empire State Building Honoring PRC 60th Anniversary Outrage], CNReviews{{Verify credibility|date=November 2009}}Chung, Jen, 1 October 2009, [http://gothamist.com/2009/10/01/empire_state_buildings_china_tribut.php Empire State Building's China Tribute Draws Protests] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208071446/http://gothamist.com/2009/10/01/empire_state_buildings_china_tribut.php |date=8 December 2009 }}, Gothamist{{Verify credibility|date=November 2009}} The lights first ignited on the eve of 30 September, and lasted for the duration of the following day. China's ally and neighbouring state, [[Pakistan]], issued a commemorative postage stamp of five rupees on 1 October.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-10/01/content_12164904.htm |title=Pakistan issues postage stamp to mark 60th anniversary of new China |author=Xinhua |publisher=chinaview.cn |date=1 October 2009}} ==Incidents and protests== ===Kyodo reporters assault=== On 18 September 2009, three employees from the Japanese [[Kyodo News]] agency were assaulted by officials in their Beijing hotel room as they tried to cover the rehearsals of the parade.{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_432953.html |work=Straits Times |author=AFP |title=Assault on reporters regretted |date= 22 September 2009 }}{{cite news |title=Chinese authorities assault 3 Kyodo News journalists in Beijing |author=AP |date= 18 September 2009}} China's Foreign Ministry stated that the reporters did not comply with a notification to news organisations to not cover the rehearsal. ===Hong Kong protests=== Approximately 800 protesters, dressed in black and holding banners, participated in a human rights protest which started at [[Chater Garden]] in [[Central, Hong Kong]]. Scuffles broke out when activists tried to carry a mock [[coffin]] to the doorstep of the liaison office.The Australian. "[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26154495-12335,00.html Hong Kong activists urge human rights.]." ''The Australian'' Retrieved on 6 October 2009.Yahoo.com. "[http://hk.news.yahoo.com/article/091001/4/ehqr.html Yahoo.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005020341/http://hk.news.yahoo.com/article/091001/4/ehqr.html |date=5 October 2009 }}." ''陶君行戴上手銬抬走.'' Retrieved on 6 October 2009. The music group [[My Little Airport]] also performed a song named "I Love The Country, But Not The Party" (我愛郊野，但不愛派對), using a [[pun]] on the 60th anniversary; its Chinese title literally translates "Country" to mean the [[rural area]] and "Party" to mean a "[[party|social gathering]]".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CcjTTDeeNFE YouTube: I love the Country, but not the Party] ==See also== Friday's]]{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/TGIFridays/status/1033028722935386112 |title=TGI Fridays on Twitter |publisher=}} |date = September 1, 2018 |attendance = 11,263{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ALL_IN_2018/status/1037028282229841920|title=All In on Twitter|publisher=Twitter|date=September 4, 2018|accessdate=September 4, 2018}} |venue = [[Sears Centre]] |city = [[Hoffman Estates, Illinois]] }} '''All In''' (stylized as '''ALL IN''') was an [[independent circuit|independent]] [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) event promoted by [[Cody Rhodes]] and [[The Young Bucks]] (Matt and Nick Jackson) from the [[Bullet Club]]. It took place on September 1, 2018 at the [[Sears Centre]] in the [[Chicago metropolitan area|Chicago suburb]] of [[Hoffman Estates, Illinois]]. The event aired live on traditional PPV outlets, Fite TV, and [[Honor Club]], and was later made available for on demand viewing on the [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling World|NJPW World]] streaming service.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/njpwglobal/status/1034615524812972033 |title=njpw global on Twitter |publisher=}} The event included ''Zero Hour'', an hour long pre-show that aired on [[WGN America]]. The event – while independently produced – featured wrestlers from [[Ring of Honor]] (ROH), [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] (NJPW), [[Impact Wrestling]], [[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide]] (AAA), and the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] (NWA). The event had eleven matches, with two being on the pre-show. The show's [[main event]] was a six-man tag team match which saw [[The Elite (professional wrestling)|The Golden Elite]] ([[Kota Ibushi]], Matt and Nick Jackson) defeat [[Rey Mysterio]], [[Fénix (wrestler)|Rey Fénix]], and [[Bandido (wrestler)|Bandido]].{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/NickJacksonYB/status/1028763185182961664 |title=The Young Bucks on Twitter |publisher=}} In the penultimate match, [[Kazuchika Okada]] defeated [[Marty Scurll]]. On the [[undercard]], [[Cody Rhodes|Cody]] defeated [[Nick Aldis]] to win the [[NWA Worlds Heavyweight Championship]], [[Jay Lethal]] (with [[Lanny Poffo]]) successfully defended the [[ROH World Championship]] against [[Flip Gordon]], and the [[IWGP Heavyweight Championship|IWGP Heavyweight Champion]] [[Kenny Omega]] defeated [[Pentagón Jr.|Penta El Zero]] in a non-title match. The event is notable for being the first non-[[WWE]] or [[World Championship Wrestling]] promoted professional wrestling event in the United States to sell 10,000 tickets since 1993.{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/ct-all-in-wrestling-chicago-young-bucks-cody-20180511-story.html |title=7 things to know about 'All In' – the huge indie wrestling show coming to the Chicago area |first=Brandon |last=Howard |publisher= |access-date=May 14, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180514064332/http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/ct-all-in-wrestling-chicago-young-bucks-cody-20180511-story.html |archive-date=May 14, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=}} == Production == === Background === In May 2017, a fan asked ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]'' journalist [[Dave Meltzer]] on [[Twitter]] if [[Ring of Honor|ROH]] could sell 10,000 tickets and Meltzer responded: "Not any time soon". [[Cody Rhodes|Cody]] took Meltzer's remark as a challenge and responded: "I'll take that bet Dave". Eventually, the idea evolved from a ROH show to a self-funded event (with ROH's official sanctioning), promoted by Cody and [[The Young Bucks]] (Matt Jackson and Nick Jackson).{{cite web |title=ROH WAR OF THE WORLDS LONDON RESULTS: BULLET CLUB VS. LIJ |url=https://www.f4wonline.com/roh-results/roh-war-worlds-london-results-bullet-club-vs-lij-241286 |website=F4wonline |accessdate=May 14, 2018 |date=August 19, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612143808/https://www.f4wonline.com/roh-results/roh-war-worlds-london-results-bullet-club-vs-lij-241286 |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=}} It was later announced that [[Kenny Omega]], [[Brandi Rhodes]], and actor [[Stephen Amell]] would be participating in the event.{{cite web |last1=Jacobs |first1=Corey |title=Stephen Amell is trying to get The Bullet Club on ‘Arrow’ |url=http://wrestlingnews.co/roh-news/stephen-amell-is-trying-to-get-the-bullet-club-on-arrow/ |website=WrestlingNews.co |accessdate=May 14, 2018 |date=December 4, 2017 margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; float: right; clear: right;" |+ '''Other on-screen personnel''' !|Role: !|Name: |- |rowspan=7|Commentators |[[Don Callis]] |- |[[Excalibur (wrestler)|Excalibur]] |- |[[Ian Riccaboni]] |- |[[Dalton Castle (wrestler)|Dalton Castle]] (Over Budget Battle Royale) |- |[[Tenille Dashwood]] (women's match) |- |[[Mandy Leon]] (women's match) |- |Brent Tarring (NWA Worlds Heavyweight Championship match) |- |rowspan=2|[[Ring announcer]]s |[[Justin Roberts]] |- |Bobby Cruise |- |rowspan=6|[[Referee (professional wrestling)|Referees]] |[[Earl Hebner]] |- |[[Jerry Lynn]] |- |Paul Turner |- |Rick Knox |- |Tiger Hattori |- |Todd Sinclair |- |rowspan=2|Interviewers |Alicia Atout |- |[[Sean Mooney]] |} === Pre-show=== Two matches were contested on the one-hour long pre-show, called ''Zero Hour'', which was shown live on [[WGN America]]. Cody and The Young Bucks opened the event and brought out [[Road Warrior Animal]]. Afterwards, Cody and The Young Bucks offered those in attendance free [[Hot Topic]] and Pro Wrestling Tees merchandise. The first match of ''Zero Hour'' featured a tag team match between SoCal Uncensored (Frankie Kazarian and Scorpio Sky) and The Briscoe Brothers (Jay Briscoe and Mark Briscoe). During the match, Jay performed a [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Double underhook piledriver|Jay-Driller]] on Kazarian and Mark also performed an Elbow Drop on Kazarian for a near-fall. In the end, The Briscoes tried to execute a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Springboard|Springboard]] [[doomsday device]] on Kazarian, but he reversed into a powerslam to win the match. Next was the Over Budget Battle Royale with the winner facing Jay Lethal for the ROH World Championship on the main card. In the climax, [[Bubba Ray Dudley|Bully Ray]] eliminated [[Colt Cabana]]. Ray thought he won, however, [[Flip Gordon]], in the guise of Chico El Luchador, appeared and eliminated Bully Ray to win the battle royale and the ROH World Championship opportunity. === Preliminary matches === The actual pay-per-view opened with MJF facing Matt Cross in singles match. In the end, Cross executed the [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Shooting star press|Shooting star press]] on MJF to win the match. Next, Christopher Daniels faced Stephen Amell. After extensive blows with Amell, Daniels pinned Amell with the [[Moonsault#Double jump moonsault|Best Moonsault Ever]] to win the match. After the match, the two shook hands. After this, Tessa Blanchard, Chelsea Green, Madison Rayne, and Dr. Britt Baker D.M.D. faced off in a four corner survival match. In the climax, Blanchard performed the [[DDT (professional wrestling)#Hammerlock DDT|Hammerlock DDT]] on Green to win the match. After the match, the four embraced. Next, Nick Aldis defended the NWA Worlds Heavyweight Championship against Cody. As Aldis went to the top rope to perform a Diving Elbow Drop, Cody's wife Brandi Rhodes tried to plead with Aldis to not do it. Aldis, however, did the move and as soon as he jumped, Brandi laid across Cody, taking the bulk of the hit. Aldis then pinned Cody, but he kicked out. Cody performed a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Springboard|Beautiful Disaster]] and then the [[Cutter (professional wrestling)#Rolling cutter|Cross Rhodes]] on Aldis for a near-fall. Cody and Aldis attacked each other with punches and then Cody hit a [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Double underhook back-to-back piledriver|Vertebreaker]] on Aldis, but Aldis reversed it. In the end, Aldis tried to steal Cody's finisher, but Cody reversed and Aldis tried to pin him, but Cody countered into a [[Pin (professional wrestling)|Sunset flip]] to win the NWA Worlds Heavyweight Championship. With this win, Cody and his father Dusty Rhodes became the first father-son duo to win the championship. In the next match, Hangman Adam Page faced Joey Janela in a Chicago Street Fight. In the end, Page performed the [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Back-to-belly piledriver|Rite of Passage]] on Janela from the top of a ladder through a table to win the match. After the match, the lights went out. Similar to [[The Undertaker]], druids appeared, but instead of druids, it was men in inflatable penis costumes. [[Joey Ryan (wrestler)|Joey Ryan]], thought to be dead, appeared and Page tried to attack him, but Ryan attacked Page and performed a [[superkick]] and Page was carried out of the arena. Next, Jay Lethal defended the ROH World Championship against the Over Budget Battle Royale winner Flip Gordon. Lethal came out in his Black Machismo gimmick. During the match, Gordon performed a [[Moonsault#Corkscrew moonsault|Stardust Press]] on Lethal for a near-fall. Lethal tried to perform a diving powerbomb, but Gordon reversed and Lethal performed a [[DDT (professional wrestling)#Diving DDT|Lethal Injection II]] on Gordon. In the end, Lethal executed the [[Powerbomb#Sitout powerbomb|Lethal Injection]] on Gordon to win the match and retain the title. After the match, the two showed mutual respect for each other. Bully Ray then came out and attacked both Lethal and Gordon. Chicago's own Colt Cabana appeared to make the save and then the three performed a triple powerbomb on Ray through a table. Next, Kenny Omega faced Penta El Zero in singles match. Omega tried to perform the [[Professional wrestling throws#Electric chair driver|One-Winged Angel]], but Penta reversed into [[Professional wrestling throws#Armbreaker|The Sacrifice]]. Penta executed the [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Package piledriver|Fear Factor]] on Omega for a nearfall and later Penta tried to perform a lariat, but Omega performed the [[Professional wrestling attacks#Knee strike|V-Trigger]] followed by a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Reverse frankensteiner|Reverse frankensteiner]]. In the end, Omega performed another V-Trigger and then the One Winged Angel to win the match. After the match, the lights went out. When they came back on, Penta got up and attacked Omega with the Codebreaker, revealing himself to be [[Chris Jericho]], who challenged Omega to a match at his Rock 'N' Wrestling Rager at Sea cruise. In the penultimate match, Kazuchika Okada faced Marty Scurll in singles match. In the end, Scurll provoked Okada and he tried to break his fingers, but Okada reverted into ''Rainmaker'' followed by a second ''Rainmaker'' to win the match. ===Main event=== In the main event, The Golden Elite (Matt Jackson, Nick Jackson, and Kota Ibushi) faced Rey Mysterio, Rey Fénix, and Bandido in six-man tag team match. Bandido hit Matt Jackson with backfliping backbreaker. Nick Jackson hit Bandido with superkick. The Young Bucks also superkicked both Fenix and Rey Mysterio. Ibushi and The Young Bucks performed the ''More Bang for Your Buck'' with Ibushi on Bandido for a nearfall. In the end, The Young Bucks performed the ''Meltzer Driver'' on Bandido to win the match. ==Reception== All In received positive critical reviews. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' called the event "near perfect pay per view debut".https://www.si.com/wrestling/2018/09/02/all-accomplishes-near-perfection-pay-view-debut?utm_campaign=sinow&utm_medium=social&xid=socialflow_twitter_si&utm_source=twitter.com John Moore of ProWrestling.net recommended the event, but pointed the event "suffers that ROH and New Japan problem of having too many matches".{{Cite web |url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/09/01/moores-all-in-live-review-kenny-omega-vs-pentagon-jr-nick-aldis-vs-cody-for-the-nwa-championship-young-bucks-and-kota-ibushi-vs-rey-mysterio-fenix-bandido-kazuchika-okada-vs-marty-sc/ |title={title} |access-date=September 1, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180902011951/https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/09/01/moores-all-in-live-review-kenny-omega-vs-pentagon-jr-nick-aldis-vs-cody-for-the-nwa-championship-young-bucks-and-kota-ibushi-vs-rey-mysterio-fenix-bandido-kazuchika-okada-vs-marty-sc/ |archive-date=September 2, 2018 |dead-url=no |df= }} Larry Csonka of ''411Mania'' gave the event a final score of 8/10, saying "I found All In to be a tremendously fun show, with a lot of good to great wrestling and an absolutely great atmosphere". During the final matches, the production found time problems, so the main event was shortened almost 12 minutes.https://www.pwinsider.com/article/120053/how-close-all-in-was-to-going-off-the-air-without-a-finish-and-more.html?p=1 Also, the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]] match went six minutes shorter than originally planned. Many wrestling personalities such as [[Tazz]] and [[Daniel Bryan|Bryan Danielson]] praised the event and its production and the quality of matches.{{cite web |title= Tazz Reviews ALL IN 2018 Chicago Results |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=DskbAb0_CmY |first= |last=Wrestling Content |date=September 3, 2018 |publisher= |via=YouTube}}{{cite web |url= https://twitter.com/WWEDanielBryan/status/1035955957048594432 |title=Daniel Bryan on Twitter |publisher=}} [[Dwayne Johnson|Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson]] praised Cody for his championship win on [[Twitter]] two days after the event.{{cite web|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/wwe/all-in-news-the-rock-comments-on-cody-rhodes-winning-the-nwa-championship|title=ALL IN News: The Rock praises Cody Rhodes for winning NWA World Heavyweight Championship|last=Cotton|first=Simon|publisher=Sportskeeda|date=September 3, 2018|accessdate=September 6, 2018}} ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]'' journalist [[Dave Meltzer]] said the event was a "great success" and "he was happy for losing the bet" [...] the event exceeded his expectations especially the Over the Budget Battle Royal, which he called the "best laid out battle royal he had ever seen".{{cite web |title= Tazz Reviews ALL IN 2018 Chicago Results Meltzer gave 6 matches 4 stars or higher with the main event receiving a 4 1/2 star rating despite the time issue surrounding it. |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=fiFAFRk9gmM&t=290s |first= |last=Wrestling Classics |date=September 3, 2018 |publisher= |via=YouTube}} Jesse Collings of the wrestlers for the first time and were not watching Being The Elite every week".http://www.wrestlinginc.com/wi/news/2018/0902/645424/views-from-the-turnbuckle-all-in-review/ Griffin Peltier from ''Voices of Wrestling'' said "ALL IN was not only a great PPV but a historic event in pro wrestling history. Everything on the show felt fresh and felt rewarded as a viewer".https://www.voicesofwrestling.com/2018/09/04/all-in-september-1-results-review/ Writing for [[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]], Mike Pielluci praised ALL IN, calling it, "one of the greatest wrestling shows in recent memory."{{Cite news|url=https://www.theringer.com/2018/9/4/17816326/all-in-cody-rhodes-young-bucks-nwa-wrestling|title=The Triumph of ‘All In’ Is Pro Wrestling’s Greatest Underdog Story|work=The Ringer|access-date=2018-09-05}} Dave Meltzer gave six matches on the card four stars or higher. {{Infobox Treaty |name = Alma-Ata Protocol |image = RIAN archive 41059 CIS heads of state.jpg |image_width = 300px |caption = Signing ceremony |type = Treaty establishing a founding declarations and principles of the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]] (CIS). |date_signed = 21 December 1991 |location_signed = [[Almaty|Alma-Ata]], [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic|Kazakhstan]] |date_sealed = |date_effective = 21 December 1991 |signatories = {{flagdeco|Russia|1991}} [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russia]]: [[Boris Yeltsin]]
{{flagdeco|Ukraine}} [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]]: [[Leonid Kravchuk]]
{{flag|Byelorussian SSR|1991|name=Belarus}}: [[Stanislav Shushkevich]]
{{flagdeco|Armenia}} [[Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic|Armenia]]: [[Levon Ter-Petrosyan]]
{{flagdeco|Azerbaijan}} [[Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan]]: [[Ayaz Mutallibov]]
{{flag|Kazakh SSR|name=Kazakhstan}}: [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]]
{{flag|Kirghiz SSR|name=Kyrgyzstan}}: [[Askar Akayev]]
{{flagdeco|Moldova}} [[Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldova]]: [[Mircea Snegur]]
{{flag|Tajik SSR|name=Tajikistan}}: [[Rahmon Nabiyev]]
{{flag|Turkmen SSR|name=Turkmenistan}}: [[Saparmurat Niyazov]]
{{flagdeco|Uzbekistan}} [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbekistan]]: [[Islam Karimov]] |depositor = |language = |languages = |wikisource =}} The '''Alma-Ata Protocols''' are the founding declarations and principles of the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]] (CIS). The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus had agreed to the [[Belavezha Accords]] on 8 December 1991, dissolving the [[Soviet Union]] and forming the CIS. On 21 December 1991, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan agreed to the Alma-Ata Protocols, joining the CIS. The latter agreement included the original three Belavezha signatories, as well as eight additional former Soviet republics. Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, and Georgia were the only former republics that have not participated. {{Cite web|url = http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/belarus/by_appnc.html|title = THE ALMA-ATA DECLARATION|website = Federal Research Division / Country Studies / Area Handbook Series / Belarus / Appendix C|publisher = Library of Congress}} More surprisingly, the protocol allowed the Russian Federation (RSFSR) to assume the Soviet Union's UN membership, including its permanent seat on the [[United Nations Security Council]]. == References == ==External links== *[http://gaidar-arc.ru/databasedocuments/theme/details/2880 The Alma-Ata Protocols (Russian language). Archive of Egor Gaidar] *[http://www.cis.minsk.by/main.aspx?uid=178 The Alma-Ata Protocols (Russian language)] *[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/belarus/by_appnc.html English translation] {{Commonwealth of Independent States}} {{Soviet Union topics}} [[Category:Commonwealth of Independent States]] [[Category:Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1991 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Treaties of Moldova]] [[Category:Treaties of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Treaties of Armenia]] [[Category:Treaties of Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Treaties of Kyrgyzstan]] [[Category:Treaties of Tajikistan]] [[Category:Treaties of Turkmenistan]] [[Category:Treaties of Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1991]] [[Category:Treaties establishing intergovernmental organizations]] {{Soviet-stub}}

[[File:Lajos Pap medium.png|thumb|[[Lajos Pap]] (middle), fraudulent apport medium.]]
In [[parapsychology]] and [[spiritualism]], an '''apport''' is the alleged [[paranormal]] transference of an article from one place to another, or an appearance of an article from an unknown source that is often associated with [[poltergeist]] activity or [[séance]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parapsych.org/historical_terms.html |title=Historical Terms Glossary |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314213256/http://archived.parapsych.org/historical_terms.html |deadurl=yes |archivedate=2016-03-14 |accessdate=2016-12-29 }}</ref><ref name= "Melton">{{cite book |last1=Melton |first1=J. Gordon |authorlink=J. Gordon Melton|title=The Encyclopedia of Religious Phenomena|date=2008|publisher=Visible Ink Press|location=Detroit |isbn=9781578592098|pages=12–13}}</ref> Apports reported during séances have been found to be the result of deliberate fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skepdic.com/apport.html |title=apport |work=[[The Skeptic's Dictionary]] |date=2015-10-27 |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> No medium or psychic has demonstrated the manifestation of an apport under scientifically controlled conditions.<ref name="Melton"/>
==History==
A famous apport fraud is attributed to [[Charles Bailey (medium)|Charles Bailey]] (1870–1947). During a [[séance]], Bailey produced two live birds out of thin air but was undone when the dealer who sold him the birds appeared in the crowd. Common objects that are produced are stones, flowers, perfumes, and animals. These objects are said to be "gifts" from the spirit(s).<ref name="Melton"/>
In March 1902 in [[Berlin]], police officers interrupted a séance of the apport medium Frau Anna Rothe. Her hands were grabbed and she was wrestled to the ground. A female police assistant physically examined Rothe and discovered 157 [[flower]]s as well as [[Orange (fruit)|oranges]] and lemons hidden in her petticoat. She was arrested and charged with fraud.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Treitel|first1=Corinna|title=A Science for the Soul: Occultism and the Genesis of the German Modern|date=2004|publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press]]|location=Baltimore, Maryland|isbn=9780801878121|page=165}}</ref> After a trial lasting six days she was sentenced to eighteen months imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Foreign Correspondence NEW YORK TIMES.E.T.H. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1903/04/11/archives/trial-of-german-medium-frau-rothe-sentenced-to-eighteen-months.html |title=TRIAL OF GERMAN MEDIUM - Frau Rothe Sentenced to Eighteen Months' Imprisonment. Produced Beautiful Flowers at Her Seances - Remarkable Evidence - How the Police Exposed the Woman. |work=The New York Times |date=1903-04-11 |accessdate=2016-12-21}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
In 1926, [[Heinrich Melzer]] was exposed as a fraud as he was caught in the séance room with small stones attached to the back of his ears by flesh coloured tape.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pslmer |first1=E. Clephan|authorlink=E. Clephan Palmer|title=The Riddle of Spiritualism|date=2003|publisher=[[Kessinger Publishing]] |isbn=9780766179318 |pages=35–39}}</ref> According to neurologist [[Terence Hines]] "Some female mediums went so far as to conceal in their vagina or anus objects to be 'apported' during the seance and gauzy fabric that would become 'ectoplasm' during the seance. These were places that Victorian gentlemen, no matter how skeptical, were highly unlikely to ask to search."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hines|first1=Terence|authorlink=Terence Hines|title=Pseudoscience and the Paranormal|date=2002|publisher=[[Prometheus Books]]|location=Amherst, New York |isbn=9781573929790|page=51|edition=2nd}}</ref>
There are many cases where apports have been smuggled into the séance room.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shepard |first1=Leslie |authorlink=Leslie Shepard |first2=Lewis|last2=Spence|authorlink2=Lewis Spence|first3=Nandor|last3=Fodor|authorlink3=Nandor Fodor|title=Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology |date=1984 |publisher=[[Gale Research Company]] |location=Detroit |isbn=9780810301962|page=504|edition=2nd}}</ref> Other apport mediums that were exposed as frauds were [[Lajos Pap]] and [[Maria Silbert]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Polidoro|first1=Massimo|authorlink=Massimo Polidoro|title=Final Seance: The Strange Friendship Between Houdini and Conan Doyle|date=2001|publisher=Prometheus Books|location=Amherst, New York|isbn=9781573928960|page=103}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gyimesi|first1=Júlia|title=Between Religion and Science: Spiritualism, Science and Early Psychology in Hungary|date=2014|pages=1–20|url=https://www.academia.edu/15777560/Spiritualism_Science_and_Early_Psychology_in_Hungary|accessdate=20 April 2017|publisher=International Psychology, Practice and Research|language=en}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2011}} In late 1934 and early 1935, the [[United Australia Party]] [[Third Lyons Ministry|Government]] of [[Joseph Lyons]] failed to exclude [[Egon Kisch|Egon Erwin Kisch]], a member of the [[Communist Party of Germany]], from entering [[Australia]]. [[File:Riksdagsbrannen.jpg|thumb|upright|Kisch was one of many members of the [[Communist Party of Germany]] arrested following the [[Reichstag fire]]; he was detained in [[Spandau Prison]] before being expelled from Germany]]
== The Raging Reporter from Prague == [[File:1933-may-10-berlin-book-burning.JPG|150px|thumb|right|Kisch's [[Nazi book burnings|books were banned and burned]] by the [[Nazi]]s.]] [[File:WillyMünzenberg2.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Willy Münzenberg set up a multitude of Communist Front organizations including the [[Movement Against War and Fascism]] (MAWF), sending Kisch to promote a Popular Front against Fascism in Australia.]]
Egon Kisch was a [[Jewish]] Communist and anti-war activist, born into the German-speaking Jewish community of Prague, [[Czechoslovakia]]. He had served in the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] during [[World War I]], had deserted, and then participated in the failed Vienna revolution of 1918. He was also the author of many travel books and a famous journalist, and as the leading proponent of German-language [[reportage]] became known to admirers and critics alike as "The Raging Reporter from [[Prague]]".
From 1925 onwards, Kisch was a speaker and operative of the [[Communist International]] and a senior figure in the publishing empire of the West European branch of the [[Communist International]] run by the Communist millionaire propagandist [[Willi Münzenberg]]. The [[Communist International]]'s 1934 policy to build [[popular front]]s of all political parties opposing Fascism was to be promoted by Kisch's Australian visit.
Kisch was a vocal critic of [[Adolf Hitler]]'s [[Nazi Party|Nazi]] regime and as a result had his books banned and burned in [[Nazi Germany|Germany]]{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}}. Following the [[Reichstag fire]], Kisch was detained in [[Spandau Prison|Spandau]] before he was expelled from Germany to his native Czechoslovakia.
== An alias and an informer == [[File:Henri-Barbusse.jpg|thumb|upright|Henri Barbusse was the secretary of the International Movement Against War and Fascism in Amsterdam]]
Experiencing the deprivations of the [[Great Depression]], 1934 Melbourne became the focus for an ideological conflict when both conservatives and socialists sought to use the centenary of the [[History of Melbourne|foundation of Melbourne]] to promote their different agendas.
Organizers of the Centenary Celebrations began by presenting an image of the city in the mould of a conservative "Britain of the Southern Hemisphere". In response, the [[Movement Against War and Fascism]] proposed holding an [[Australasia]]n conference, timed to coincide with the British Royal Tour of the celebrations. Invitations to speakers and delegates were sent throughout Australia and New Zealand. An international speaker was sought from the World Committee Against War, one of the many communist front organizations run by the West European [[Communist International]]. On 5 October 1934, French Communist [[Henri Barbusse]], acting for the [[Communist International]], placed an announcement in the Melbourne ''[[The Herald (Melbourne)|Herald]]'' stating:
:"Herr Egon Erwin Kisch, a German novelist, whose writing satirising the Hitler regime caused him to be sent to Nazi concentration camps for political prisoners, will be a visitor here for the [[1934 Centenary of Melbourne|Centenary celebrations]]... He will speak on conditions in Germany during his tour of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]."
[[File:Blamey.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Victoria Police Commissioner Major-General Sir Thomas Blamey informed the Lyons Government that Kisch should be excluded.]]
Inspector Ronald Browne of the Investigation Branch discovered from an informant that the World Committee Against War (one of the many Communist [[front organisation]]s known as the Münzenberg Trust) was sending a "Ewart Risch" as a speaker to the All Australian Congress of the [[Movement Against War and Fascism]] held at the [[Port Melbourne Town Hall]], Melbourne on 10–12 November 1934.
When the Investigation Branch discovered that "Ewart Risch" was Egon Kisch, known to the British [[Special Branch]] as a militant Communist opponent of the Nazis, Victoria Police Commissioner [[Thomas Blamey|Major-General Sir Thomas Blamey]], informed [[Thomas Paterson]], the federal Minister for the Interior. Paterson then made a declaration of exclusion against Kisch under the [[Immigration Restriction Act 1901]].
== Unwelcome == [[File:EgonKischStrathaird1934SamHood.JPG|thumb|upright|Kisch on board the ''Strathaird'', bound for Australia]] [[File:KischMelbourne1934.JPG|upright|thumb|left|Kisch greets supporters with the clenched fist Communist Salute before making his famous leap from the ''Strathaird''.]] Kisch arrived in [[Fremantle]] on 6 November 1934 on the [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company|P&O]] liner [[RMS Strathaird|RMS ''Strathaird'']].
The ship was promptly boarded by representatives of the Federal Government who refused Kisch entry to Australia on the ground that he was "undesirable as an inhabitant of, or visitor to, the Commonwealth".
Kisch professed to be deeply hurt and was sure that things would be put right once he was given a chance to explain. He was scrupulous, however, in denying his membership of the Communist Party of Germany.
Kisch was required to stay in the custody of Captain Carter on board the ''Strathaird'' as it proceeded through Australian waters via [[Adelaide]], Melbourne and [[Sydney]].
== Leap into history == [[File:Robert Menzies 1930s.jpg|upright|thumb|left|[[Attorney-General of Australia|Attorney-General]] Robert Menzies prosecuted the Lyons Government's case against Kisch]] On 12 November 1934, large groups of Kisch supporters gathered in Melbourne and the ''Strathaird'' was surrounded by boatloads of Kisch well-wishers. The [[International Labor Defense|International Labour Defence]] (another Münzenberg Trust front) engaged Melbourne barrister [[Joan Rosanove]], who, with a group of Kisch supporters, went aboard the ''Strathaird'' and initiated a ''[[habeas corpus]]'' action.
The Melbourne court hearing the action delayed any immediate decision on Kisch, leaving him in custody aboard the ''Strathaird'' as it departed the city.
On 13 November, Kisch defied Australian authorities when he jumped over five metres from the deck of the ''Strathaird'' onto Melbourne's [[Station Pier]], breaking his right leg. The [[Victoria Police]] quickly took charge of Kisch and carried him back on board the ''Strathaird''.
The next day, the issue rose to national prominence when Labor MP for [[Division of Batman|Batman]], [[Frank Brennan (politician)|Frank Brennan]] rose in the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] to accuse the Lyons government of cowardice. He asked why Kisch's right to speak in Australia was being restricted just because the Lyons administration disagreed with him.
In response, the [[Attorney-General of Australia|Attorney-General]] [[Robert Menzies]] pointed out that every civilized country had the right to determine who should or should not be allowed in, and that, since Kisch was a revolutionary and since revolution involved violence, he was not to be permitted entry.
==Kisch's legal supporters act== [[File:H. V. Evatt in 1925.jpg|thumb|upright|High Court Justice Evatt authorised Kisch to visit Australia, finding that the Lyons Government had failed to list the reason for Kisch's exclusion in their order]] As the ''Strathaird'' made its way up Australia's east coast to Sydney, supporters of Kisch took his case before [[High Court of Australia|High Court]] [[H. V. Evatt|Justice Evatt]], who found that the Federal Government had incorrectly excluded Kisch from Australia because they had failed to list in their order the advice received from the British Government. Evatt released Kisch and ordered that he be free to visit as long as he respected the laws of Australia.<ref>{{cite AustLII|HCA|50|1934|litigants=R v Carter; Ex parte Kisch |date=16 November 1934 |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1934/50.pdf (1934) 52 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 221] |courtname=auto}}.</ref>
== The Government uses the dictation test == The ''Strathaird'' arrived in Sydney Harbour on 16 November 1934. The Federal Government now attempted to exclude Kisch using the [[Immigration Restriction Act 1901|Immigration Restriction Act]]. The Act as amended in 1905 provided that "any person who (...) when an officer dictates to him not less than fifty words in any prescribed language, fails to write them out in that language in the presence of the officer" would not be admitted.<ref>{{cite Legislation AU|Cth|num_act|iraa1905171905384|Immigration Restriction Amendment Act 1905}}.</ref>
This was primarily intended, and used, as a means to exclude non-whites from entering Australia under the [[White Australia Policy]], but it could be, and occasionally was, used to exclude other undesirables. Kisch demonstrated his fluency in a number of European languages, and he was then asked to write the [[Lord's Prayer]] in [[Scottish Gaelic]]. He refused to participate and was deemed to have failed the test. He was then taken into custody, this time by the [[New South Wales Police Force|New South Wales police]], who released him on [[Australian pound|AU£]]200 bail.
The dictation test was also used to exclude another anti-war activist who had been invited to speak. Irishman (and therefore British subject) Gerald Griffin, had been given a dictation test in Dutch, which he had failed as he was meant to do. In his memoir ''Australian Landfall'', Kisch records with gusto how Griffin then entered Australia under a false name and led the authorities a merry dance as he popped up unannounced to speak at meeting after meeting.
==A literary reception== Kisch attended a [[Fellowship of Australian Writers]] luncheon in honour of British [[poet laureate]] [[John Masefield]], along with [[Albert Piddington]], [[Kenneth Slessor]] and [[Norman Lindsay]]. Controversy ensued when three government ministers and several writers mounted objections.
The Movement Against War and Fascism organized a Kisch reception committee including [[Katharine Susannah Prichard]], [[Vance Palmer|Vance]] and [[Nettie Palmer]], [[E. J. Brady]] and [[Louis Esson]]. This group formed the nucleus of what later became the Writers League, drawing on the example of Egon Kisch's own journalistic dedication to reportage. The reception committee organized concerts featuring performances from Greek, Italian, Yugoslav, Jewish, Russian and [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] artists with the theme of international opposition to [[Fascism]].
==The High Court rules== [[File:Maurice Blackburn oilpainting1942 (cropped).jpg|upright|thumb|left|Labor Parliamentarian and [[Movement Against War and Fascism|MAWF]] member Maurice Blackburn acted as one of Kisch's legal counsel]] [[File:Albert Piddington.jpg|thumb|upright|Sydney's Red [[King's Counsel|KC]] Albert Piddington represented Kisch, with Smith and Blackburn]]
Egon Kisch's legal team was headed by [[Christian Jollie Smith]], who secured a writ of ''[[habeas corpus]]'' for Kisch and briefed [[Albert Piddington]] and [[Maurice Blackburn]], who took his case to the full bench of the High Court, which on 19 December 1934 ruled that he be free to visit Australia. Kisch's legal team were able to demonstrate that Constable Mackay, who had administered the test, although born in Scotland, was not actually able to understand the Lord's Prayer in Scottish Gaelic himself. Crucially, the Court ruled that the dictation test had been invalid in any case, in that Scottish Gaelic was not "a European language" within the meaning of the ''Immigration Restriction Act''.<ref>{{cite AustLII|HCA|63|1934|litigants=R v Wilson ; Ex parte Kisch |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1934/63.pdf (1934) 52 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 234] |date=19 December 1934 |courtname=auto}}.</ref> Kisch was now free to visit and speak in Australia. Or so it seemed.
==Prime Minister Lyons intervenes== [[File:Joseph Aloysius Lyons portrait, 1930s.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Australian Prime Minister Joseph Lyons acted to exclude Kisch a third time]] In December 1934 the [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian Prime Minister]] [[Joseph Lyons]] contacted the British Government and received the following written advice: ''Position is that Egon Kisch was refused leave to land in the United Kingdom in September 1933 on account of his known subversive activities stop permission to enter the United Kingdom would now not be granted to him stop [[James Henry Thomas|Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs]] stop''
The government then made a second declaration under the Immigration Restriction Act, overcoming the technical shortcoming which Evatt had found in the first, and on 21 January 1935 the Central Sydney Police Court convicted Kisch of being a prohibited immigrant and sentenced him to three months imprisonment with [[Penal labour|hard labour]]. However, Kisch was released on bail when his lawyer took an appeal to High Court [[H. V. Evatt|Justice Evatt]], who again ruled that Kisch be set free. Evatt pointed out that, under the law, the minister had no power to rule on immigration matters after a person had entered Australia and he set up a hearing of the Full Bench of the High Court for March.
==Kisch free== [[File:Kischdomain1935.JPG|thumb|Kisch addressed a crowd of 18,000 in Sydney's Domain, telling Australians of his first-hand experience with the dangers of the Nazi regime]]
Kisch was free to move about and speak. He became a popular figure, addressing meetings, rallies and crowds in [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], warning of the dangers of the Nazi regime. On 17 February 1935, he addressed an estimated 18,000-strong audience in [[The Domain, Sydney|Sydney's ''Domain'']]:
:"I have had three adventurous months since I last saw you. I know the [[Police Courts|Police Court]], the [[Quarter Sessions|Quarter Sessions Court]], the [[High Court of Australia|High Court]] with one judge and the High Court with five judges. But whenever the court let me go I was arrested again. I have learnt to speak English better. Perhaps I do not speak King's English but it's Kisch English anyhow. I did not come here to tell there is terrorism in Europe. I come here to tell you how to stop it. I have been an eye-witness. I was arrested the day the [[Reichstag fire|Reichstag]] was burnt down by [[Hermann Göring|Göring]] and his lieutenants. I saw my friend, [[Erich Mühsam]], the poet, whose works I translated, made to walk naked, even in winter, and to lick up the spittle of his captors. All his limbs were broken gradually, and he died."
== The Government does a deal == Facing the dilemma that further persecution and legal wrangling simply promoted Kisch’s cause, the Lyons Government proposed a compromise. On 26 February 1935, the Melbourne ''[[The Argus (Melbourne)|Argus]]'' reported: :"Provided that Egon Erwin Kisch, the Czechoslovakian author, gives certain undertakings to the authorities, the Federal Ministry is willing to recommend [[Isaac Isaacs|His Excellency]] the [[Governor-General of Australia|Governor-General]] to remit the sentence of imprisonment for three months with hard labour imposed on him in Sydney ... there is no desire on the part of the Ministry to compel him to serve a term of imprisonment if he is willing to leave immediately."
Ultimately, the Lyons government agreed to cut its losses and offered to remit Kisch's sentence, stop all legal proceedings and pay Kisch [[Australian pound|AU£]]450 for his costs in exchange for an agreed exit date of 11 March 1935. Having achieved notoriety above and beyond anyone's expectations, and public exposure of his warnings of Adolf Hitler and the dangers of fascism, Kisch accepted their offer and departed Sydney on the [[Orient Steam Navigation Company|Orient]] liner ''Ormonde'', bound for Marseille.
== Legacy ==
In response to their humiliation, the Lyons Government introduced a new law, whereby a person charged as a prohibited immigrant became ineligible for bail.
The dictation test was used again in 1936, controversially and for reasons that were never made clear, to exclude Mabel Freer, a white British woman born in India, who was confronted with a test in Italian.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robertson|first1=Kel|title=Dictating to One of ‘Us’: the Migration of Mrs Freer|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/MqLJ/2005/12.html|website=Macquarie Law Journal|publisher=Australasian Legal Information Institute|accessdate=2017-04-26|date=2005}}</ref> Interior Minister [[Thomas Paterson]] resigned from the Lyons Cabinet following the controversy. The test was not abolished until 1958.
Kisch detailed his antipodean adventures in his 1937 book ''Australian Landfall''. He returned to Czechoslovakia in 1946. Following his death in 1948 he was acknowledged as a hero of the [[German Democratic Republic]]. [[File:Stamps of Germany (DDR) 1985, MiNr Zusammendruck 2940.jpg|thumb|Kisch and his birth house portrayed on a stamp issued by the [[East Germany|GDR]] to celebrate the centenary of his birth]]
The Kisch Welcome Committee developed into a literary appreciation society known as the Writers League.
Maurice Blackburn was expelled from the [[Australian Labor Party]] over his membership of the [[Movement Against War and Fascism]] and its links to the Communist Party. As a consequence he was defeated in his electorate of [[Division of Bourke|Bourke]]. However his Wife [[Doris Blackburn]] successfully contested Bourke and served as an independent after her husband's death.
The [[Communist International]] policy of creating a united front against fascism in Australia was successfully resisted by Australia's mainstream political parties. The Australian Labor Party opposed links and cooperation with the Communist Party which remained isolated and marginalized.
Melbourne communist writer [[Frank Hardy]] detailed Kisch's Australian visit in his fictionalized version of [[John Wren|John Wren's]] life, ''[[Power Without Glory]]'' (1950). In 1976 this story was adapted for television by the Australian Broadcasting Company in which Egon Kisch was played by Kurt Ludescher.
[[Robert Menzies]] visited Germany in August 1938, as Attorney-General of Australia in the pro-[[appeasement]] Lyons government. Menzies spent several weeks in Nazi Germany and was extremely impressed with the achievements of the "New Germany", and on his return gave public talks expressing warm approval of the Hitlerite dictatorship, as he said, "based on my personal experience". Menzies later attempted to distance himself from the Kisch affair, claiming the debacle had been initiated by Thomas Paterson and that his own involvement had just been a mistake. In 1951 Christian Jollie Smith worked with H. V. Evatt to prevent an attempt by Menzies (now Prime Minister) to ban the Communist Party in Australia.
