{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Racine County Jane Doe | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = File:Racine Jane Doe.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = Digital image created from study of morgue photographs to depict an estimation of the victim in life | caption = 2012 reconstruction created by the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] | birth_name = | birth_date = 1964-1981 (approximate) | birth_place = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = {{Unidentified for|1999|7|21}} | death_date = July 20 or 21, 1999
(aged 18 - 35) | death_place = | death_cause = [[Homicide]] by [[blunt force trauma]] | body_discovered = July 21, 1999
[[Raymond, Wisconsin]] | resting_place = Raymond, Wisconsin, United States | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = "Crystal Rae" | known_for = Unidentified victim of homicide | height = {{height|ft=5|in=8|abbr=mos}} | weight = {{convert|120|lb|kg}} | website = [https://www.facebook.com/pages/Jane-Doe-Racine-County-Wisconsin/233409330015328 Facebook page] }} '''Racine County Jane Doe''' (informally known as '''Crystal Rae''') was a young white woman whose body was discovered in 1999 in the town of [[Raymond, Wisconsin|Raymond]], [[Racine County]], [[Wisconsin]]. The victim was aged 18 to 35 years at the time of her death, which occurred after weeks of neglect and torture.{{cite web|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/199ufwi.html|title=Case File 199UFWI|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=April 16, 2014}} New developments in the case emerged after her body was [[Exhumation|exhumed]] on October 16, 2013. It is not known how successfully these leads have been followed.{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Mike|title=Investigators still believe Racine County Jane Doe case can be solved|url=http://www.wisn.com/news/south-east-wisconsin/racine-kenosha/investigtors-still-believe-racine-county-jane-doe-case-can-be-solved/22494034|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=WISN|date=October 17, 2013}} ==Discovery of the body== The body was found near a field on July 21, 1999, apparently within one day after being disposed of.{{cite news|title=Racine Jane Doe body exhumed 14 years later|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?id=9299571|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=ABC News}} One of the two people who discovered the body stated that an arm appeared to be broken, since it was in an unnatural position. Because it had rained on the night the body was dumped, little evidence of the perpetrator was found. An [[autopsy]] indicated that she had died from multiple injuries, such as burning and beating, and had endured several weeks of neglect and abuse, which had increased a few days before she died.{{cite web|title=Police release new photo of Jane Doe found in 1999|url=http://www.wisn.com/news/south-east-wisconsin/racine-kenosha/Police-release-new-photo-of-Jane-Doe-found-in-1999/17748238|publisher=WISN|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=December 12, 2012}} She showed signs of having been malnourished and [[sexual abuse|sexually abused]].{{cite news|last=Tenuta|first=Marci Laehr|title=Authorities continue working 12-year-old homicide case ‘that burns in all of our minds’|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/local/authorities-continue-working--year-old-homicide-case-that-burns/article_e0907cae-c1b5-11e0-8e1d-001cc4c03286.html|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=Journal Times|date=August 8, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Leshchinskaya|first=Nastacia|title=Unsolved Murder Spotlight: The Racine County Jane Doe |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/blog/article/unsolved-murder-spotlight-the-racine-county-jane-doe/index.html|publisher=Crimelibrary.com|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=May 20, 2013}} A "cauliflower ear" deformity may have been caused by the abusive conditions in which she lived.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe's Body Exhumed|publisher=Racine County Sheriff Department|url=http://www.racinesheriff.org/news|accessdate=April 16, 2014|year=2014}} Over 50 people attended the woman's [[funeral]] after the [[autopsy]] was completed.{{cite web|title=Racine County Jane Doe, WI|url=http://www.meyahna.tripod.com/pg23.html|accessdate=13 July 2014}} Her [[gravestone]] reads "Daughter: Jane Doe", along with the relevant dates.{{cite news|last=Handelman|first=Ben|title=Racine Jane Doe investigation continues with new leads|url=http://fox6now.com/2013/10/25/racine-jane-doe-investigation-continues-with-new-leads/|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=Fox News|date=October 25, 2013}} ==Description== [[File:Racine Jane Doe2.jpg|thumb|left|Original reconstructions of the victim, made before the 2012 composite was created.]] The [[malnutrition|malnourish]]ed woman may have been [[intellectual disability|mentally disabled]]. She had a "[[cauliflower ear]]" deformity, which likely resulted from abuse. It is believed that she was most likely 18 to 30 years old, although she may have been up to 35.{{cite web|title=Crystal Rae - 1999 Unidentified Racine, Wisconsin (92nd Street, Town of Raymond)|url=http://canyouidentifyme.blogspot.com/2007/10/crystal-rae-1999-unidentified-racine.html|accessdate=13 July 2014|date=4 October 2007}}{{cite news|title=Unsolved Homicide-Jane Doe, Racine County|url=http://racineuncovered.org/2015/06/racine-county-sheriffs-unsolved-homicide-jane-doe/|accessdate=20 July 2015|work=Racine Uncovered News|date=28 June 2015}} Her teeth were not well cared for. Her front [[incisor]]s protruded from the mouth, and decay was present on many teeth. Some teeth were missing. Her curly hair was reddish-brown, collar-length, and appeared to have blond [[Hair highlighting|highlights]]. Her eyes were either brown, green, or hazel. There were two [[earring]]s in each of her ears. She had visible bruises and cuts across her body, and a fractured nose.{{cite news|last1=Bauter|first1=Alison|title=Who is she? Updated image of 1999 Jane Doe released|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/who-is-she-updated-image-of-jane-doe-released/article_81c9670a-4475-11e2-a5b4-001a4bcf887a.html|accessdate=3 July 2015|work=The Journal Times|date=12 December 2012}}{{cite web|title=Who is Racine County Jane Doe, Tortured, Killed in 1999?|url=http://coldcaseusa.blogspot.com/2011/08/who-is-racine-jane-doe-tortured-killed.html|website=Cold Case USA|publisher=Blogger|accessdate=3 July 2015}} She wore a man's shirt, gray in color, with a floral design on the front. After contacting the shirt's manufacturer, it was learned that this type of shirt was first sold in 1984. She was also wearing black [[sweatpants]]. She was not wearing shoes. ==Investigation== [[File:Racine Jane Doe Reconstruction.jpg|thumb|right|Another rendering of Racine County Jane Doe.]] Multiple [[forensic facial reconstruction|reconstructions]] were made of the victim's face . In 2012, an additional reconstruction was created by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.{{cite news|last1=Bohr|first1=Nick|title=New image released of Jane Doe found in Racine in 1999|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yk0PIbHHEdU|accessdate=30 November 2014|work=WISN 12 News|publisher=ABC|date=12 December 2012}} Another version of the composite exists, which shows a different facial expression. At one time, she was thought to be [https://www.facebook.com/FindAundriaMBowman/ Aundria Bowman], who was presumed to have run away from her adoptive parents' house in [[Hamilton, Michigan]] on March 11, 1989, but [[DNA profiling]] via her mother Cathy, demonstrated that they were not the same person. [[Missing person]]s such as Aundria, Tina D'Ambrosio, and Karen Wells have been ruled out.{{cite web|title=Racine County, Wisconsin Jane Doe 7/21/1999|url=http://www.missinginamerica.us/apps/blog/categories/show/1561472-racine-county-wi-jane-doe|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=December 16, 2012}}{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4741|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/4741|website=NamUs.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=11 June 2014}}{{cite web|title=Case File 184DFMI|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/184dfmi.html|publisher=The Doe Network|accessdate=4 June 2014}} Some believed that this case could be linked to the murder of Mary Kate Chamizo (née: Sunderlin), a previously unidentified victim who was discovered in [[Lake County, Illinois]]. Sunderlin was also found malnourished, had poor dentition and had been beaten to death. Three were arrested in that case; one was convicted.{{cite news|last1=Tunkieicz|first1=Jenny|title=Investigators find ties between Jane Doe, Illinois case|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1683&dat=20000721&id=HHcfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qS8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4507,497867|accessdate=16 August 2014|agency=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=21 July 2000}}{{cite web|title=Identified - Index 5|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/identified5.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=16 August 2014}} The remains were [[exhumation|exhumed]] on October 16, 2013, for further study and transported to [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], where the body had previously been examined in 1999.{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Stephanie|title=Jane Doe's body exhumed for testing; Sheriff 'determined' to ID her|url=http://journaltimes.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/jane-doe-s-body-exhumed-for-testing-sheriff-determined-to/article_946dbbd6-36a5-11e3-a79b-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=3 July 2015|work=The Journal Times|date=16 October 2013}} Authorities hoped that by studying the [[bone]]s, they would be able to tell where the woman had lived prior to her death. It was announced on July 19, 2015, that the examination of the remains had been completed and that they would be reburied on July 21 on the 16th anniversary of their discovery.{{cite news|title=Jane Doe to be reinterred on July 21st, 2015|url=http://racineuncovered.org/2015/07/jane-doe-to-be-reinterred-on-july-21st-2015/|accessdate=20 July 2015|work=Racine Uncovered News|date=19 July 2015}} Authorities stated they had indeed uncovered new leads from the exhumation, but they declined to state any details.{{cite news|last1=Bohr|first1=Nick|title=Racine County Jane Doe reburied|url=http://www.wisn.com/news/racine-county-jane-doe-reburied/34282906|accessdate=24 July 2015|work=NowCast|publisher=ABC|date=21 July 2015}} On October 20, 2016 it was announced that chemical isotope testing performed by the [[Smithsonian]] on a sample of her hair and bone suggest she may originally have been from or spent several years of her life in [[Alaska]], [[Montana]] or portions of southern [[Canada]]. Authorities did not comment on what testing the results are from, whether recent with hair or history from bone.{{cite news|title=New information learned about Racine County Jane Doe's past|url=http://www.wisn.com/article/new-information-learned-about-racine-county-jane-does-past/7007615 |accessdate=28 January 2018|work=ABC 12 WISN|date=4 January 2017}} Although the murder remains unsolved, investigators hope that the case will eventually come to a close. A press conference in 2013 is said to have uncovered more clues.{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Anna|title=Could she finally be named? Police confident they can identify Jane Doe murdered 14 years ago using new technology|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2464196/Police-confident-Jane-Doe-murdered-14-years-ago-using-new-technology.html|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=Mail Online|date=October 17, 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Unidentified murder victims}} *{{NCMEC UID|1101693}} *{{Doe Network|199ufwi.html}} *{{NamUs|4741}} *{{Find a Grave|13583756|Racine County Jane Doe}} {{Unidentified decedent}} [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century births]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Female murder victims]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:People from Racine County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:People murdered in Wisconsin]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:Racine County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Sexual assaults in the United States]] [[Category:Torture in the United States]] [[Category:Unidentified murder victims in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]]

{{short description|opera house and major performing arts venue in Covent Garden, central London}} {{About|the opera house in London|the post-1945 opera company|The Royal Opera|other uses|Royal Opera (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Royal Opera House |logo_image = Royal Opera House logo.jpg |logo_caption = Logo of the Royal Opera House |image = Royal Opera House and ballerina.jpg |caption = The Royal Opera House's Bow Street frontage with [[Enzo Plazzotta|Plazzotta]]'s statue, ''Young Dancer'', in the foreground |address = [[Bow Street]] |city = London, [[WC postcode area|WC2]] |country = United Kingdom |publictransit = {{rint|london|underground}} {{lus|Covent Garden}} |designation = [[Listed building|Grade I]]<ref>{{NHLE |num=1066392 |desc=The Royal Opera House |date=9 January 1970 |access-date=9 July 2015}}</ref> |latitude = |longitude = |architect = |owner = |capacity = 2,256 |type = [[Opera house]] |opened = |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = [http://www.roh.org.uk www.roh.org.uk] }}
The '''Royal Opera House (ROH)''' is an [[opera house]] and major performing arts venue in [[Covent Garden]], [[central London]]. The large building is often referred to as simply '''"Covent Garden"''', after a previous use of the site of the opera house's original construction in 1732. It is the home of [[The Royal Opera]], [[The Royal Ballet]], and the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House. Originally called the '''Theatre Royal''', it served primarily as a playhouse for the first hundred years of its history. In 1734, the first ballet was presented. A year later, [[Handel]]'s first season of operas began. Many of his operas and [[oratorio]]s were specifically written for Covent Garden and had their premieres there.
The current building is the third theatre on the site following disastrous fires in 1808 and 1856. The façade, [[foyer]], and [[auditorium]] date from 1858, but almost every other element of the present complex dates from an extensive reconstruction in the 1990s. The main auditorium seats 2,256 people, making it the third largest in London, and consists of four tiers of [[box (theatre)|box]]es and [[balcony|balconies]] and the [[amphitheatre]] gallery. The [[proscenium]] is 12.20 m wide and 14.80 m high. The main auditorium is a Grade I [[listed building]].<ref>[http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/443-royal-opera-house-london "Royal Opera House (London)"] description on theatrestrust.org.uk Retrieved 10 May 2013</ref>
==The Davenant Patent== [[Image:Rich-Covent-Garden.jpg|thumb|"Rich's Glory": John Rich seemingly invades his new Covent Garden Theatre. (caricature by [[William Hogarth]])]] The foundation of the '''Theatre Royal, Covent Garden''' lies in the [[letters patent]] awarded by [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] to Sir [[William Davenant]] in 1662, allowing Davenant to operate one of only two [[patent theatre]] companies (''The [[Duke's Company]]'') in London. The letters patent remained in the possession of the patentees' heirs until the 19th century; their whereabouts are currently unknown.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-london/vol35/pp1-8#h3-0004 'The Killigrew and Davenant patents' ''Survey of London'' vol. 35 pp 1-8.]</ref>
==The first theatre== [[Image:Covert Garden Theatre edited.jpg|thumb|upright|Illustration of the first theatre before it burned down in 1808]] In 1728, [[John Rich (producer)|John Rich]], actor-manager of the Duke's Company at [[Lincoln's Inn Fields]] Theatre, commissioned ''[[The Beggar's Opera]]'' from [[John Gay]]. The success of this venture provided him with the capital to build the Theatre Royal (designed by [[Edward Shepherd]]) at the site of an ancient convent garden, part of which had been developed by [[Inigo Jones]] in the 1630s with a piazza and church. In addition, a Royal Charter had created a fruit and vegetable market in the area, a market which survived in that location until 1974. At its opening on 7 December 1732, Rich was carried by his actors in processional triumph into the theatre for its opening production of [[William Congreve]]'s ''[[The Way of the World]]''.<ref>Admission to the 55 boxes was 5 shillings (1/4 [[Pound sterling|£]]), half a crown (1/8 £) to the 'pit', and the gallery cost one shilling (1/20 £). A seat on the stage cost ten shillings. It was allowed to send servants to arrive at three to save places on the stage for their masters and mistresses. £115 was taken at the box office on the first night.</ref>
During the first hundred years or so of its history, the theatre was primarily a playhouse, with the Letters Patent granted by Charles II giving Covent Garden and [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] exclusive rights to present spoken drama in London. Despite the frequent interchangeability between the Covent Garden and Drury Lane companies, competition was intense, often presenting the same plays at the same time. Rich introduced [[pantomime]] to the repertoire, himself performing (under the stage name ''John Lun'', as [[Harlequin]]) and a tradition of seasonal pantomime continued at the modern theatre, until 1939.<ref>[http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/collections/object.php?object_id=285&ter=true&ter_id=83&back=%2Fcollec ''John Rich as Harlequin'']{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (PeoplePlayUK – Theatre Museum) accessed 22 July 2008.</ref>
In 1734, Covent Garden presented its first ballet, ''Pygmalion''. [[Marie Sallé]] discarded tradition and her corset and danced in diaphanous robes.<ref>[http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/yiannis/dance/history.html ''Early ballet history''] (North Eastern University) accessed 22 December 2006.</ref> [[George Frideric Handel]] was named musical director of the company, at Lincoln's Inn Fields, in 1719, but his first season of opera, at Covent Garden, was not presented until 1734. His first opera was ''[[Il pastor fido]]'' followed by ''[[Ariodante]]'' (1735), the première of ''[[Alcina]]'', and ''[[Atalanta (opera)|Atalanta]]'' the following year. There was a royal performance of ''[[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]'' in 1743, which was a success and began a tradition of [[Lent]]en oratorio performances. From 1735 until his death in 1759 he gave regular seasons there, and many of his operas and oratorios were written for Covent Garden or had their first London performances there. He bequeathed his organ to John Rich, and it was placed in a prominent position on the stage, but was among many valuable items lost in a fire that destroyed the theatre on 20 September 1808. In 1792<ref>Sheppard, p. 91</ref> the architect [[Henry Holland (architect)|Henry Holland]] rebuilt the auditorium, within the existing shell of the building but deeper and wider than the old auditorium, thus increasing capacity.
==The second theatre== [[Image:Covent-garden-1.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Satirical drawing, 1811, of the "Pigeon Holes" that flanked the upper gallery at Covent Garden]] [[Image:New Covent Garden Theatre Microcosm edited.jpg|thumb|upright|1810 illustration of the auditorium of the second theatre]] [[Image:Joseph Grimaldi.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Joseph Grimaldi]], as [[Harlequinade#Clown|Clown]]]] Rebuilding began in December 1808, and the second Theatre Royal, Covent Garden (designed by [[Robert Smirke (architect)|Robert Smirke]]) opened on 18 September 1809 with a performance of ''[[Macbeth]]'' followed by a musical entertainment called ''The Quaker''. The actor-manager [[John Philip Kemble]], raised seat prices to help recoup the cost of rebuilding and the cost of an increased ground rent introduced by the landowner, the Duke of Bedford, but the move was so unpopular that audiences disrupted performances by beating sticks, hissing, booing and dancing. The ''[[OP Riots|Old Price Riots]]'' lasted over two months, and the management was finally forced to accede to the audience's demands.<ref>[http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/drama_tour/19th_century/victorian_riots.php ''The Old Price Riots''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531162120/http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/drama_tour/19th_century/victorian_riots.php |date=31 May 2008 }} (PeoplePlayUK – the Theatre Museum (at the [[V & A]]) accessed 1 July 2006.</ref>
During this time, entertainments were varied; opera and ballet were presented, but not exclusively. Kemble engaged a variety of acts, including the child performer ''[[Master Betty]]''; the great [[clown]] [[Joseph Grimaldi]] made his name at Covent Garden. Many famous actors of the day appeared at the theatre, including the tragediennes [[Sarah Siddons]] and [[Eliza O'Neill]], the [[Shakespeare]]an actors [[William Charles Macready]], [[Edmund Kean]] and his son [[Charles Kean|Charles]]. On 25 March 1833 Edmund Kean collapsed on stage while playing [[Othello]], and died two months later.<ref>[http://www.nndb.com/people/318/000102012/ Edmund Kean (1789–1833)] (NNDB) accessed 22 July 2008.</ref>
In 1806, the [[pantomime]] clown Joseph Grimaldi (''The Garrick of Clowns'') had performed his greatest success in ''[[Mother Goose|Harlequin and Mother Goose; or the Golden Egg]]'' at Covent Garden, and this was subsequently revived, at the new theatre. Grimaldi was an innovator: his performance as ''Joey'' introduced the clown to the world, building on the existing role of [[Harlequin]] derived from the ''[[Commedia dell'arte]]''. His father had been ballet-master at Drury Lane, and his physical comedy, his ability to invent visual [[Magic (illusion)|tricks]] and [[buffoon]]ery, and his ability to poke fun at the audience were extraordinary.<ref>[http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/pantomime_tour/early_pantomime/grimaldi.php ''Early Pantomime''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505042950/http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/pantomime_tour/early_pantomime/grimaldi.php |date=5 May 2008 }} (PeoplePlayUK – the Theatre Museum (at the [[V & A]]) accessed 22 July 2008.</ref>
Early pantomimes were performed as [[mime]]s accompanied by music, but as [[Music hall]] became popular, Grimaldi introduced the [[pantomime dame]] to the theatre and was responsible for the tradition of audience singing. By 1821 dance and clowning had taken such a physical toll on Grimaldi that he could barely walk, and he retired from the theatre.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/MemoirsOfJosephGrimaldi "Boz" (ed.) ([[Charles Dickens]]), ''Memoirs of Joseph Grimaldi'', 1853 edition with Notes and Additions by [[Charles Whitehead]], accessed 22 February 2007].</ref> By 1828, he was penniless; Drury Lane held a benefit concert for him after Covent Garden refused.<ref>Arundell, Dennis, ''The Story of Sadler's Wells''</ref>
[[Image:Covent Garden Theatre 1827-28.jpg|thumb|The theatre in the 1820s]] [[File:An Apology To The Town, For Himself And The Bottle.png|thumb|left|upright|''Harlequin's escape into the bottle'' (print)]] In 1817, bare flame gaslight had replaced the former candles and oil lamps that lighted the Covent Garden stage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Theatres Compete in Race to Install Gas Illumination – 1817|url=http://www.overthefootlights.co.uk/1817-18.pdf|work=Over The Footlights|accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> This was an improvement, but in 1837 Macready employed [[limelight]] in the theatre for the first time, during a performance of a pantomime, ''Peeping Tom of Coventry''. Limelight used a block of [[quicklime]] heated by an oxygen and hydrogen flame. This allowed the use of spotlights to highlight performers on the stage.<ref>Banham, p. 1026</ref>
The [[Theatres Act 1843]] broke the patent theatres' monopoly of drama. At that time [[Her Majesty's Theatre]] in the Haymarket was the main centre of ballet and opera but after a dispute with the management in 1846 [[Michael Costa (conductor)|Michael Costa]], conductor at Her Majesty's, transferred his allegiance to Covent Garden, bringing most of the company with him. The auditorium was completely remodeled after an 1846 fire, during the following 1846–47 seasons, the company performed at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]].<ref>"Madame Parepa-Rosa", ''[[Illustrated London News]]'', 7 February 1874, p. 129; and Obituary: "Madame Parepa Rosa", ''The Times'', 23 January 1874, p. 10</ref> The theatre reopened as the '''Royal Italian Opera''' on 6 April 1847 with a performance of [[Gioacchino Rossini|Rossini]]'s ''[[Semiramide]]''.<ref>[http://www.roh.org.uk/about/royal-opera-house/history/ History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407064033/http://www.roh.org.uk/about/royal-opera-house/history |date=7 April 2014 }} (Royal Opera House) accessed 18 December 2012.</ref>
In 1852, [[Louis Antoine Jullien]] the French eccentric composer of light music and conductor presented an opera of his own composition, ''Pietro il Grande''. Five performances were given of the 'spectacular', including live horses on the stage and very loud music. Critics considered it a complete failure and Jullien was ruined and fled to America.<ref>[http://louisjullien.site.voila.fr ''Louis-Antoine Jullien'' (in French)] accessed 21 December 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Jullien, Louis Antoine |volume=15 |page=551}}</ref> Costa and his successors presented all operas in Italian, even those originally written in French, German or English, until 1892, when [[Gustav Mahler]] presented the debut of Wagner's [[Ring cycle]] at Covent Garden.{{sfn|Parker|1900|p=39}}<ref>[[Anton Seidl]] had conducted the very first Ring in England (sung in German) at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]] from 5–9 May 1882. Source: {{cite journal |journal=The Musical Times |volume=47 |issue=763 |title=Wagner's Music in England |author=F. G. E. [F. G. Edwards] |date=1 September 1906 |p=593 |jstor=903478}} (Free registration required)</ref> The word "Italian" was then quietly dropped from the name of the opera house.<ref name=Ivanhoe>Gordon-Powell, Robin. ''Ivanhoe'', full score, Introduction, vol. I, p. VIII, 2008, The Amber Ring</ref>
==The third theatre== On 5 March 1856, the theatre was again destroyed by fire. Work on the third theatre, designed by [[Edward Middleton Barry]], started in 1857 and the new building, which still remains as the nucleus of the present theatre, was built by [[Lucas Brothers (company)|Lucas Brothers]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/49439 |title=Charles Thomas Lucas at Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |publisher=Oxforddnb.com |date= |accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref> and opened on 15 May 1858 with a performance of [[Giacomo Meyerbeer|Meyerbeer's]] ''[[Les Huguenots]]''.
The Royal English Opera company under the management of [[Louisa Pyne]] and [[William Harrison (singer)|William Harrison]], made their last performance at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] on 11 December 1858 and took up residence at the theatre on 20 December 1858 with a performance of [[Michael Balfe]]'s ''Satanella''<ref>''Reviews'', "Drury-Lane Theatre", [[The Times]]'', 13 December 1858, p. 10.</ref> and continued at the theatre until 1864.
The theatre became the '''Royal Opera House''' (ROH) in 1892, and the number of French and German works offered increased. Winter and summer seasons of opera and ballet were given, and the building was also used for pantomime, recitals and political meetings.
During the [[First World War]], the theatre was requisitioned by the Ministry of Works for use as a furniture repository.
From 1934 to 1936, [[Geoffrey Toye]] was managing director, working alongside the Artistic Director, [[Thomas Beecham|Sir Thomas Beecham]]. Despite early successes, Toye and Beecham eventually fell out, and Toye resigned.<ref>Jefferson, p. ?</ref>
During the [[Second World War]] the ROH became a dance hall. There was a possibility that it would remain so after the war but, following lengthy negotiations, the music publishers [[Boosey & Hawkes]] acquired the lease of the building. [[David Webster (opera manager)|David Webster]] was appointed General Administrator, and [[Sadler's Wells Ballet]] was invited to become the resident ballet company. The Covent Garden Opera Trust was created and laid out plans "to establish Covent Garden as the national centre of opera and ballet, employing British artists in all departments, wherever that is consistent with the maintenance of the best possible standards ..."<ref>Rosenthal, p. ?</ref>
The Royal Opera House reopened on 20 February 1946 with a performance of ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' in an extravagant new production designed by [[Oliver Messel]]. Webster, with his music director [[Karl Rankl]], immediately began to build a resident company. In December 1946, they shared their first production, [[Henry Purcell|Purcell]]'s ''[[The Fairy-Queen]]'', with the ballet company. On 14 January 1947, the Covent Garden Opera Company gave its first performance of [[Bizet]]'s ''[[Carmen]]''.
Before the grand opening, the Royal Opera House presented one of the Robert Mayer Children's concerts on Saturday, 9 February 1946.
==Reconstruction from the 1980s forward== [[File:Royal Opera House at night.jpg|thumb|left|The Royal Opera House, Bow Street Façade, after reconstruction]]
Several renovations had taken place to parts of the house in the 1960s, including improvements to the amphitheatre but the theatre clearly needed a major overhaul. In 1975 the Labour government gave land adjacent to the Royal Opera House for a long-overdue modernisation, refurbishment, and extension. In the early 1980s the first part of a major renovation included an extension to the rear of the theatre on the James Street corner. The development added two new ballet studios, offices, a Chorus Rehearsal Room and the Opera Rehearsal room. Dressing rooms were also added. [[File:ROH auditorium 003.jpg|thumb|right|The Royal Opera House auditorium, stage to the left]] [[File:ROH auditorium 001.jpg|thumb|right|Facing the stage from the Amphitheatre]] By 1995, sufficient funds from the Arts Lottery through [[Arts Council England]]<ref>[http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/uploads/documents/publications/annualreview0504_php4iC12j.rtf ''Arts Council England annual review 2005'', part 4 of 4] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904115441/http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/uploads/documents/publications/annualreview0504_php4iC12j.rtf |date=4 September 2012 }} on artscouncil.org.uk Retrieved 10 May 2013</ref> and private fundraising had been raised to enable the company to embark upon a major £213 million reconstruction of the building by [[Carillion]],<ref>[http://www.carillionplc.com/sectors/sectors_leisure_opera.asp Royal Opera House case study on carillionplc.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104225125/http://carillionplc.com/sectors/sectors_leisure_opera.asp |date=4 January 2010 }} Retrieved 24 March 2012</ref> which took place between 1997 and 1999, under the chairmanship of [[Angus Stirling|Sir Angus Stirling]]. This involved the demolition of almost the whole site including several adjacent buildings to make room for a major increase in the size of the complex. The auditorium itself remained, but well over half of the complex is new.
The design team was led by Jeremy Dixon and [[Edward Jones (English architect)|Edward Jones]] of Dixon Jones [[Building Design Partnership|BDP]] as architects. The acoustic designers were Rob Harris and Jeremy Newton of Arup Acoustics. The building engineer was [[Arup Group Limited|Arup]] with Stanhope as developer.<ref>[http://www.stanhopeplc.com/?page=21&id=236 Stanhope company website] on stanhopeplc.com Retrieved 10 May 2013</ref>
[[File:Floral Street, Covent Garden - geograph.org.uk - 1550247.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Sky bridge connects the [[Royal Ballet School]] (left) to the Royal Opera House (right) on the 4th floor. The bridge was designed by [[Wilkinson Eyre Architects]]]]
The new building has the same traditional horseshoe-shaped auditorium as before, but with greatly improved technical, rehearsal, office, and educational facilities. Additionally, a new studio theatre, the Linbury, as well as more public space was created. The inclusion of the adjacent old Floral Hall, which had fallen into disrepair and was used as a scenery store before redevelopment, created a new and extensive public gathering place. The venue is now claimed by the ROH to be the most modern theatre facility in Europe.
[[Surtitle]]s, projected onto a screen above the proscenium, have been used for all opera performances since they were introduced for schools matinees in 1984. Since the reopening of the theatre in 1999 an [[Electronic libretto|electronic libretto system]] provides translations onto small video screens for some seats, and additional monitors and screens are to be introduced to other parts of the house.
In 2014 design work, known as the Open Up Project, began with the aim of improving the entrances, lobby areas and the Linbury Theatre.<ref>[http://www.architectnews.co.uk/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=396:royal-opera-house-launches-open-up-project-with-architects&Itemid=90 "Royal Opera House launches 'Open Up' project with architects"], on architectnews.co.uk</ref><ref>Elizabeth Hopkirk, [http://www.building.co.uk/stanton-williams-unveils-%C2%A337m-royal-opera-house-revamp/5071884.article "Stanton Williams unveils £37m Royal Opera House revamp"], 3 November 2014, on architectnews.co.uk. (with images)</ref>
==Facilities== ===Paul Hamlyn Hall=== [[File:Royal Opera House - Floral Hall - Bow Street - London - 240404.jpg|thumb|Exterior of the Paul Hamlyn Hall]]
The Paul Hamlyn Hall is a large iron and glass structure adjacent to, and with direct access to, the main opera house building. The hall now acts as the atrium and main public area of the opera house, with a champagne bar, restaurant and other hospitality services, and also providing access to the main auditorium at all levels.
The redevelopment of the Floral Hall went ahead on the strength of a pledge of £10m from the philanthropist [[Alberto Vilar]] and for a number of years, it was known as the Vilar Floral Hall; however Vilar failed to make good his pledge. As a result, the name was changed in September 2005 to the Paul Hamlyn Hall, after the opera house received a donation of £10m from the estate of [[Paul Hamlyn]], towards its education and development programmes.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6638245.stm "£10m pledged to Royal Opera House", 9 May 2007 on news.bbc.co.uk] Retrieved 24 March 2012</ref>
As well as acting as a main public area for performances in the main auditorium, the Paul Hamlyn Hall is also used for hosting a number of events, including private functions, dances, exhibitions, concerts, and workshops.
===Linbury Studio Theatre=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Royal Opera House - Linbury Studio Theatre.jpg|thumb|left|Linbury Studio Theatre – View from the stage]] -->
The Linbury Studio Theatre is a flexible, secondary performance space, constructed below ground level within the Royal Opera House. It has retractable raked seating and a floor which can be raised or lowered to form a studio floor, a raised stage, or a stage with orchestra pit. The theatre can accommodate up to 400 patrons and host a variety of different events. It has been used for private functions, traditional theatre shows, and concerts, as well as community and educational events, product launches, dinners and exhibitions, etc., and is one of the most technologically advanced performance venues in London with its own public areas, including a bar and cloakroom. <ref>[http://londondance.com/directory/venues/dance/linbury-studio-theatre/ Linbury Studio Theatre on londondance.com] Retrieved 24 March 2012</ref><ref>[http://everything2.com/title/Royal+Opera+House Royal Opera House on everything2.com] Retrieved 24 March 2012</ref>
The Linbury is most notable for hosting performances of experimental and independent dance and music, by independent companies and as part of the ROH2, the contemporary producing arm of the Royal Opera House. The Linbury Studio Theatre regularly stages performances by the [[Royal Ballet School]] and also hosts the [[Young British Dancer of the Year]] competition.
The venue was constructed as part of the 90s redevelopment of the Royal Opera House. It is named in recognition of donations made by the Linbury Trust towards the redevelopment. The Trust is operated by [[Lord Sainsbury of Preston Candover]] and his wife [[Anya Linden]], a former dancer with the Royal Ballet. The name Linbury is derived from the names Linden and Sainsbury.<ref>[http://www.linburytrust.org.uk/ The Linbury Trust on linburytrust.org.uk] Retrieved 24 March 2012</ref> It was opened in 1999 with a collaboration from three [[Croydon]] secondary schools (including [[Coloma Convent Girls' School]] and [[Edenham High School]]) in an original performance called ''About Face''.<ref>{{cite web|title=UKTW Archive, London Royal Opera House|url=https://www.uktw.co.uk/archive/London/Royal-Opera-House/Dance/About-Face/L022557777/|website=UK Theatre Web|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref>
===Royal Opera House, Manchester=== {{main|The Royal Ballet#Royal Opera House.2C Manchester}}
In 2008 the Royal Opera House and [[Manchester City Council]] began planning stages a new development known as '''Royal Opera House, Manchester'''. The proposal would have seen the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester|Palace Theatre]] in Manchester refurbished, to create a theatre capable of staging productions by both the [[The Royal Ballet|Royal Ballet]] and the Royal Opera. It was intended that the Royal Opera House would take residence of the theatre for an annual 18-week season, staging 16 performances by the Royal Opera, 28 performances by the Royal Ballet and other small-scale productions.<ref>{{cite news | last = Higgins | first = Charlotte | title = Disharmony over Royal Opera's plan to go north | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/28/royal-opera-lowry-manchester | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 28 October 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Northern opera proposal evaluated | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7702690.stm | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 31 October 2008 }}</ref> A year later [[The Lowry]] sent an open letter to the then [[Secretary of State for Culture, Olympics, Media and Sport]], [[Ben Bradshaw]], Arts Council England, Manchester City Council and the ROH, calling for the scheme, in its current form, to be scrapped.<ref>{{cite news | last = Brown | first = Mark | title = Threat to plan for Royal Opera House in the north | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/25/lowry-manchester-royal-opera-house | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 25 June 2009 }}</ref> In 2010 it was announced that the project was being shelved as part of larger arts-funding cuts.<ref name="Stage_031110">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = ROH shelves its plans to move north | url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2010/roh-shelves-its-plans-to-move-north/ | work = [[The Stage]] | publisher = The Stage Media Company Ltd | date = 3 November 2010 }} [http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/2252-roh-shelves-its-plans-to-move-north Alternative link.]</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Sharp | first = Rob | title = Royal Opera House shelves move north | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/classical/news/royal-opera-house-shelves-move-north-2118505.html | work = [[The Independent]] | publisher = Independent Print Ltd | date = 27 October 2010 }}</ref>
===High House Production Park (High House, Purfleet)=== [[File:Royal Opera House production facility.JPG|thumb|300px|ROH's Manoukian Production Facility at [[High House, Purfleet]]]] The Royal Opera House opened a scenery-making facility for their operas and ballets at [[High House, Purfleet]], Essex on 6 December 2010. The building was designed by Nicholas Hare Architects.<ref name="EEDA">[http://www.eeda.org.uk/5894.asp "Thurrock launches new creative and cultural hub", 13 December 2010, East of England Development Agency press release on its website eeda.org.uk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718095403/http://www.eeda.org.uk/5894.asp |date=18 July 2011 }} Retrieved 9 January 2011</ref> The East of England Development Agency, which partly funded developments on the park, notes that "the first phase includes the Royal Opera House's Bob and Tamar Manoukian Production Workshop and Community areas".<ref name="EEDA"/>
The Bob and Tamar Manoukian Costume Centre, also designed by Nicholas Hare Associates, opened in September 2015, and provides a costume-making facility for the Royal Opera House and a training centre for students of costume-making from [[South Essex College]]. The building also houses the Royal Opera House's collection of historically important costumes.
Other elements at High House, Purfleet include The Backstage Centre, a new technical theatre and music training centre which is currently run by the National College for Creative Industries and was formally opened by [[Creative & Cultural Skills]] in March 2013, alongside renovated farm buildings. Acme studios opened a complex of 43 artist studios in Summer 2013.<ref> [http://blog.roh.org.uk/?cat=53&paged=2 Information (with illustration) about the Production Park from blog.roh.org.uk] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110918173937/http://blog.roh.org.uk/?cat=53&paged=2 |date=18 September 2011 }} Retrieved 25 November 2010</ref>
==Opera at the Royal Opera House after 1945== {{For|events in the history of opera at Covent Garden after 1945|The Royal Opera}}
==Ballet at the Royal Opera House after 1945== {{For|events in the history of ballet at Covent Garden after 1945|The Royal Ballet}}
==Other uses== In addition to opera and ballet performances, the Royal Opera House has hosted a number of other events including: *'''[[Laurence Olivier Awards]]''' – 2012 to 2016 *'''[[British Academy Film Awards]]''' – 2008 to Present

{{One source|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox recurring event |name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> |native_name = |native_name_lang = |logo = |logo_alt = |logo_caption = |logo_size = |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |status = Active |genre = Conventions |date = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} "dates=" also works, but do not use both --> |begins = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} --> |ends = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|mm|dd}} --> |frequency = Annually |venue = Business design centre, Islington, London |location = London, UK |coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|type:event|display=inline,title}} --> |country = England |years_active = <!-- {{age|YYYY|mm|dd}} Date of the first occurrence --> |first = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|mm|dd}} "founded=" and "established=" also work --> |founder_name = <!-- or | founders = --> |last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> |prev = |next = September 2018 |participants = |attendance = |capacity = |area = |budget = |activity = |leader_name = |patron = |organised = <!-- "organized=" also works --> |filing = |people = |member = |sponsor = <!-- | or sponsors = --> |website = <!-- {{http://thephilatelictraderssociety.co.uk/stampex/}} --> |current = |footnotes = }} [[File:Spring Stampex 2011.jpg|right|thumb|Spring Stampex 2011.]] '''Stampex''' is a twice yearly British [[stamp show]] held at the [[Business Design Centre]] (BDC) at Islington, London, every Spring and Autumn. The show is organised by the [[Philatelic Traders Society]] (PTS) through their company ''PTS Stamp and Coin Exhibitions Limited'' and has been running for many years. The next exhibition will be held on 12-15 September 2018.
==Elements of the show== The show consists mainly of stands from stamp dealers who are members of the PTS but specialist [[philatelic]] societies often hold meetings at the BDC in conjunction with the show.
Until recently competitive stamp exhibitions were also held. The Association of British Philatelic Societies (ABPS) has announced that they will be reintroduced with effect from the Autumn 2009 show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukphilately.org.uk/abps/latestnews/ABPS_Competitions.html |accessdate=June 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203231454/http://www.ukphilately.org.uk/abps/latestnews/ABPS_Competitions.html |archivedate=December 3, 2008 }}</ref>
Other important parts of the show include a youth area run by the National Youth Stamp Group and a large stand from Britain's [[Royal Mail]] where recent British stamp issues are on sale.
==Souvenirs== Admission is free of charge and visitors usually receive a modest philatelic souvenir of some kind. At the Spring 2009 show a postcard was given featuring unadopted artwork by stamp designer [[Jeffery Matthews]] for a proposed 1979 Welsh Assembly stamp issue. These souvenirs have become collectable. Each Stampex issues a Smilers Sheet (released in conjunction with Stanley Gibbons, the official sponsors of Stampex, and Royal Mail) available for purchase as well as a free commemorative postcard.
==History== Stampex has not always been at the BDC. For many years it was located at the Central Hall, Westminster when it was organised between the PTS and The Junior Philatelic Society (now the [[National Philatelic Society]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lookandlearn.com/childrens-newspaper/CN630316-010.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Children's Newspaper |date=16 March 1963 |website=Lookandlearn.vom |accessdate=2016-02-04}}</ref>
== Other British shows == There is no other regular national show competing with Stampex in the UK, although many smaller shows take place and an [[Fédération Internationale de Philatélie|FIP]] endorsed international show takes place in London every ten years, with the next being the London 2020 International Stamp Exhibition.
The name has been adopted for stamp shows in other countries, for instance Hong Kong Stampex and Adelaide Stampex, however, none are connected with the British version.
==See also== *[[List of philatelic exhibitions (by country)]]

The '''Tentacles Convention''' was an international [[role-playing game]] [[Gaming convention|convention]] held annually at [[Stahleck Castle]] in Germany on [[Pentecost]]. Tentacles was dedicated to games set in [[Glorantha]] such as ''[[HeroQuest (role-playing game)|HeroQuest]]'' and ''[[RuneQuest]]'', as well as ''[[Call of Cthulhu (role-playing game)|Call of Cthulhu]]'', ''[[Stormbringer (role-playing game)|Stormbringer]]'' and ''[[Hawkmoon (role-playing game)|Hawkmoon]]''.
Tentacles Convention was hosted by the ''RuneQuest Gesellschaft e.V.'' (better known outside of Germany as ''The Chaos Society'') every year from 1996 to 2009. During that time, Tentacles, and [[Convulsiion]] followed by [[Continuum Conventions|Continuum]] were the only periodically held [[Glorantha]] conventions in Europe. Most of the about 180 guests were fans and authors of the supported game systems. The publishers [[Chaosium]], [[Issaries, Inc.]] and MoonDesign used Tentacles as a forum for presenting and discussing the plans of their games.
Due to the international audience English was the main language. Tentacles offered the only opportunity in Germany to get in touch with two founders of role-playing [[Greg Stafford]] and [[Sandy Petersen]]. Sandy Petersen and other invited authors regularly wrote game modules and articles especially for Tentacles Convention. These works were published in the ''Ye Booke of Tentacles (YboT)''-almanacs which are treasured by Glorantha and English-speaking Cthulhu fans.
A notable type of games on Tentacles was the [[freeform role-playing game]].
==External links== * [http://www.tentacles-convention.de/ Official Homepage of the Tentacles Convention] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061017045317/http://www.glorantha.com/tribes/tentacles2006.html Report on the convention] by Greg Stafford * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928055730/http://www.chaosium.com/article.php?story_id=159&submit=email&slashSess=ff73b38c83dde9103de3fcca5fccbde0 Report on the convention] by [[Charlie Krank]]
